Je me propose aujourd‚Äôhui d‚Äôapprofondir cette piste am√©ricaine, en esp√©rant que cela permettra de r√©√©quilibrer un peu les d√©bats, qui penchent dangereusement vers une forme d‚Äôatlantisme primaire teint√© de conspirationnisme. Les faits articul√©s ci-dessous sous forme de chronologie ne doivent en aucun cas √™tre interpr√©t√©s comme un faisceau de preuves. Enfin et surtout, il ne faut pas oublier que des centaines de publications scientifiques sugg√®rent que l‚Äô√©mergence du virus est tr√®s certainement naturelle et qu‚Äôune erreur humaine est au contraire improbable. On sait que les humains c√¥toient les chauve-souris sur tous les continents, on sait que les transmissions animal-homme sont fr√©quentes et l‚Äôon conna√Æt les m√©canismes g√©n√©raux qui gouvernent ce processus.

Le 11 juillet 2019, une √©pid√©mie de pneumonie se d√©clare dans une maison de retraite en Virgine, sur la c√¥te est des √âtats-Unis (#11, #12). D‚Äôautres √©v√©nements similaires se produisent √† proximit√© et les services de sant√© de Virginie signalent entre 16 et 19 √©pid√©mies locales de maladies respiratoires durant l‚Äô√©t√© 2019 (#14, #15, #16), ce qui constitue un bilan anormal pour ce petit √©tat de la c√¥te est am√©ricaine.

Si EVALI n‚Äôest √©videmment pas consid√©r√©e comme contagieuse contrairement √† Covid-19, il faut signaler que le temps d‚Äôincubation tr√®s long de Covid-19 rend la d√©tection des cha√Ænes de contagion bien plus difficile que pour d‚Äôautres virus.

Le propos n‚Äôest donc pas d‚Äôidentifier Covid-19 √† EVALI, ni de nier qu‚ÄôEVALI existe en tant que telle, mais seulement de signaler que les m√©canismes de veille √©pid√©miologique ont pu dysfonctionner en raison de la co-occurence de deux probl√®mes ind√©pendants dont les manifestations cliniques se recoupent.

A l‚Äô√©pid√©mie de pneumonie associ√©e au vapotage succ√®de l‚Äô√©pid√©mie de grippe, bien connue pour g√©n√©rer des sympt√¥mes relativement proches de Covid-19, dont des difficult√©s respiratoires pouvant aller jusqu‚Äô√† la pneumonie. Or, fin novembre - d√©but d√©cembre 2019, de nombreuses r√©gions signalent l‚Äô√©mergence pr√©coce de sympt√¥mes ressemblant √† la grippe (‚Äúflu-like symptoms‚Äù) et de maladies respiratoires (#30, #31, #32, #33, #34, #35). Au niveau f√©d√©ral, les donn√©es indiquent que l‚Äô√©pid√©mie de grippe a commenc√© avec presqu‚Äôun mois d‚Äôavance cette ann√©e (#36) et qu‚Äôune surmortalit√© est observ√©e par rapport aux ann√©es pr√©c√©dentes (#37).



Pourcentage de visites pour cause de sympt√¥mes grippaux fin 2019, d√©but 2020. Source: Center for Disease Control.


Contrairement √† EVALI, la grippe peut faire l‚Äôobjet d‚Äôun test virologique formel. Cependant, √† regarder les donn√©es de pr√®s, la quantit√© d‚Äô√©chantillons recueillis est infime par rapport au nombre de cas recens√©s (de l‚Äôordre de quelques centaines pour plusieurs centaines de milliers de cas) et seulement 10 √† 15% des √©chantillons montrent une infection par le virus de la grippe (#38).
Dans la perspective d‚Äôune origine am√©ricaine pr√©c√©dant l‚Äôexplosion des cas √† Wuhan, il est donc envisageable que les √©pid√©mies d‚ÄôEVALI et de grippe aient contribu√© √† faire passer Covid-19 sous le radar des autorit√©s.


Janvier 2020: arriv√©e officielle de Covid-19 sur le sol am√©ricain et scandale li√© aux tests d√©fectueux
Le 20 Janvier 2019, Covid-19 fait officiellement son entr√©e sur le sol am√©ricain (#40, #41). C‚Äôest le CDC qui annonce le premier r√©sultat positif. Cette institution √©tant la seule √† √™tre habilit√©e par la Food and Drug Administration (FDA), tous les premiers tests sont en effet effectu√©s en interne. Mais confront√© √† une demande croissante, le CDC annonce qu‚Äôil va commencer √† envoyer des kits de test √† divers h√¥pitaux du pays le 27 janvier et met simultan√©ment en ligne son protocole (#42). Une semaine plus tard les kits sont finalement envoy√©s en tr√®s faible quantit√© (environ 200; #43, #44).
Malheureusement, d√®s le 12 f√©vrier, de nombreux articles de presse indiquent que les kits en question sont d√©fectueux et que leurs r√©sultats seront donc ininterpr√©tables (#45), probl√®me reconnu d√®s le lendemain par le CDC qui annonce envoyer des kits de substitution (#46). Pourtant, deux longues semaines plus tard, les √âtats-Unis n‚Äôont encore test√© que 426 personnes, alors que la Cor√©e du Sud en a d√©j√† test√© 35000 (#47).
Au moment o√π Trump annonce que l‚Äô√©pid√©mie est ‚Äúsous contr√¥le‚Äù et insiste dans les m√©dias pour d√©fendre l‚Äôaction des pouvoirs publics jug√©e ‚Äúappropri√©e‚Äù (#48), la pol√©mique enfle dans les laboratoires nationaux et les instituts de recherche, qui peinent √† obtenir l‚Äôautorisation n√©cessaire pour produire leurs propres tests. L‚Äôarticle tr√®s d√©taill√© du New Yorker sur le sujet est √©loquent: ce n‚Äôest que le 29 f√©vrier que la FDA a autoris√© un laboratoire autre que le CDC √† diagnostiquer Covid-19, et ces autorisations ont d‚Äôabord √©t√© donn√©es au compte-goutte, en raison des lenteurs du syst√®me administratif (#49).


Avril 2020, plus de 700 000 am√©ricains contamin√©s par le virus et des questions sans r√©ponses
Deux mois plus tard, les √âtats-Unis sont une des nations les plus touch√©es par l‚Äô√©pid√©mie (#50). Ce bilan catastrophique s‚Äôexplique en partie par l‚Äôincapacit√© de la super-puissance √† mettre au point un test efficace avant la fin du mois de f√©vrier, alors m√™me que la technologie n√©cessaire est utilis√©e depuis vingt ans dans d‚Äôinnombrables laboratoires √† travers le monde (#51).
Les nombreux foyers d‚Äôinfections pass√©s sous les radars de la CDC ont √©videmment contribu√© √† cette √©volution rapide. Mais compte tenu de la chronologie d√©taill√©e ci-dessus, on peut l√©gitimement se demander depuis quand Covid-19 est pr√©sent sur le territoire am√©ricain. Est-il possible que l‚Äô√©pid√©mie ait commenc√© aux √âtats-Unis √† travers des cha√Ænes de contagion courtes, en Virginie et dans les √©tats voisins, avant de se d√©guiser sous les traits d‚Äôune √©pid√©mie de pneumonie li√©e au vapotage dont la manifestation clinique est proche de celle de Covid-19?
En th√©orie, ces questions pourraient recevoir une r√©ponse positive, si les cas de pneumonie suspects mentionn√©s ci-haut √©taient test√©s r√©trospectivement pour Covid-19. On imagine d‚Äôailleurs que le CDC s‚Äôest pos√© la question d‚Äôun lien entre l‚Äô√©pid√©mie de Covid-19 et l‚Äô√©pid√©mie de pneumonie li√©e au vapotage. Cependant, si le r√©sultat des tests effectu√©s au d√©but de la pand√©mie ne peut √™tre interpr√©t√©s en raison des erreurs techniques qui font aujourd‚Äôhui scandale, cette question restera peut-√™tre en suspens pour toujours.
Insinuer qu‚Äôil n‚Äôest peut-√™tre pas dans l‚Äôint√©r√™t de l‚Äôadministration am√©ricaine de r√©v√©ler de tels r√©sultats serait verser dans un proc√®s d‚Äôintention qui n‚Äôa pas sa place ici. En revanche, si l‚Äôon accepte l‚Äôhypoth√®se d‚Äôune √©mergence am√©ricaine, rien n‚Äôemp√™che d‚Äôexaminer de potentiels √©v√©nements d√©clencheurs.
√âvidemment, rien n‚Äôexclut une contagion animal-homme sur le sol am√©ricain, puisque les chauve-souris am√©ricaines constituent aussi ‚Äî √† l‚Äôinstar de leurs cong√©n√®res africaines, europ√©ennes ou chinoises ‚Äî un r√©servoir de coronavirus (#52, #53, #54). Cependant, si le virus a √©merg√© naturellement, il est bien plus plausible que l‚Äô√©v√©nement ait eu lieu en Chine, en raison de la proximit√© entre Covid-19 et un coronavirus de chauve-souris d√©couvert sur le territoire chinois (le fameux BatCov-RaTG13).
En d‚Äôautres termes, si l‚Äôon se tourne vers l‚ÄôOuest, il est logique d‚Äôexaminer au contraire la possibilit√© d‚Äôune erreur humaine, et en particulier, la possibilit√© d‚Äôun incident impliquant les laboratoires de l‚ÄôUSAMRIID bas√©s √† Fort Detrick (Maryland).


Retour en ao√ªt 2019: fermeture soudaine du laboratoire de Fort Detrick
Le 2 ao√ªt 2019, le CDC ordonne la fermeture soudaine des laboratoires P3 et P4 de Fort Detrick dans le Maryland (#55), deux semaines apr√®s l‚Äô√©pid√©mie de pneumonie suspecte ouvrant la chronologie ci-dessus. A Fort Detrick, situ√© √† seulement 65 kilom√®tres de la maison de retraite de Greenspring, l‚Äôarm√©e am√©ricaine effectue des travaux de recherche sur les agents infectieux les plus dangereux au monde, dont le bacille de la peste ou le virus Ebola. De nombreux m√©dias am√©ricains reprennent alors cette information et rappellent que Fort Detrick est connu non seulement pour son r√¥le historique dans les programmes de bio-armement am√©ricains, mais √©galement pour son implication probable dans le scandale des enveloppes contamin√©es √† l‚Äôanthrax en septembre 2001 (#56, #57, #58).
Le probl√®me d√©tect√© par les autorit√©s fut apparemment multifactoriel, sans que l‚Äôon sache lequel a √©t√© d√©terminant dans la fermeture du site: certaines proc√©dures ne respectaient pas les normes √©tablies, certains membres du personnel n‚Äôavaient pas re√ßu la formation ad√©quate et une faille fut d√©couverte dans le syst√®me de d√©contamination de l‚Äôeau. Cette faille datant apparemment de mai 2018, lorsque des inondations ont endommag√© le circuit d‚Äôeau de l‚Äôinstitut (#59), c‚Äôest donc un peu plus d‚Äôun an de recherche qui a √©t√© effectu√© dans des conditions de s√©curit√© d√©fectueuses.



Centre de recherche de l‚Äôarm√©e am√©ricaine √† Fort Detrick. Source: Wikimedia Commons.


Sans entrer dans les d√©tails, on rel√®vera √©galement que ces anomalies s‚Äôinscrivent dans un contexte tr√®s particulier: celui d‚Äôune bataille juridique entre Battelle Memorial Institute ‚Äî l‚Äôentreprise priv√©e exploitant le site ‚Äî et Laulima Government Solutions √† propos de la gestion du processus de d√©contamination dudit site (voir la d√©cision du gouvernement am√©ricain dans cette opposition: #60). En octobre 2019, Laulima, qui proposait un projet √† 150 millions de dollars contre 190 pour Battelle, finit par obtenir gain de cause et devient responsable de la d√©contamination, malgr√© une exp√©rience apparemment limit√©e en la mati√®re. S‚Äôil peut para√Ætre surprenant qu‚Äôun laboratoire d‚Äôune telle importance strat√©gique pour l‚Äôarm√©e am√©ricaine soit administr√© par une entreprise priv√©e soumise √† des imp√©ratifs de profitabilit√©, c‚Äôest en r√©alit√© chose commune aux √âtats-Unis. A elle seule, l‚Äôentreprise Battelle administre directement 9 grands centres de recherche sur le territoire am√©ricain (#61). Le centre de Fort Detrick est quant √† lui administr√© par une de ses filiales, Tunnel Governement Services (#62).
Bien que les coronavirus ne soient pas la sp√©cialit√© de Fort Detrick, on sait que certaines recherches ont r√©cemment port√© sur le coronavirus MERS (voir cette publication de 2018, #63). On sait aussi que ce laboratoire a d√©j√† utilis√© une technologie de pointe nomm√©e CRISPR-Cas9 pour extraire s√©lectivement certaines s√©quences g√©n√©tiques de plusieurs virus dont Ebola (#64). Et pas n‚Äôimportent quelles s√©quences. En effet, l‚Äôobjectif de l‚Äôarticle en question √©tait d‚Äôextraire les s√©quences codant pour un ‚Äúcleavage furin site‚Äù qui est √©galement impliqu√© dans la virulence de Covid-19 et dont la pr√©sence dans le g√©nome de Covid-19 est consid√©r√©e comme ‚Äúinattendue‚Äù par les chercheurs (#65, #66, #67).
Faut-il croire, sur la base de ces informations, que Covid-19 est n√© d‚Äôune erreur humaine √† Fort Detrick et qu‚Äôil s‚Äôest propag√© silencieusement aux √âtats-Unis avant de muter √† Wuhan pour finalement produire la pand√©mie qui nous afflige?
Non. Il faut continuer d‚Äôassocier √† cette hypoth√®se une probabilit√© tr√®s faible et privil√©gier l‚Äôavis ultra-majoritaire chez les chercheurs d‚Äôapr√®s qui le virus a √©merg√© naturellement, en Chine, √† la suite de la contamination directe d‚Äôun homme par une chauve-souris ou par un animal interm√©diaire qui reste √† d√©couvrir.
Tout au plus peut-on utiliser les informations rapport√©es ici pour √©viter d‚Äô√™tre entra√Æn√©s √† l‚Äôaveugle dans la strat√©gie de Trump, Mike Pompeo, Fox News, et dans une moindre mesure Emmanuel Macron ou d‚Äôautres chefs d‚Äô√âtats occidentaux. prompts √† insinuer que la Chine est moralement responsable de la pand√©mie (#68, #68, #70, #71).
En effet, d‚Äôapr√®s un rapport au Congr√®s am√©ricain datant de 2018 (#72), la gestion des laboratoires P3 et P4 est loin d‚Äô√™tre irr√©prochable aux √âtats-Unis. Source de scandales par le pass√©, ces laboratoires sont √† la fois plus anciens et plus nombreux qu‚Äôen Chine. Leur exploitation par des entreprises priv√©es permet en outre d‚Äô√©mettre des doutes vis-√†-vis de leur fiabilit√©, dans un contexte de r√©duction des co√ªts et de difficult√©s √©conomiques accentu√©es par l‚Äôarriv√©e de Trump au pouvoir (#73).
Si la recherche sur les virus reste √©videmment n√©cessaire, nombreux sont les experts qui craignent que certains P3 et P4 ne constituent de v√©ritables bombes √† retardement (#80, #81, #82). La pand√©mie de Covid-19 et les soup√ßons qu‚Äôelle suscite pourraient ainsi √™tre l‚Äôoccasion d‚Äôune prise de conscience collective: la multiplication progressive de ces laboratoires entra√Æne, math√©matiquement, une multiplication des risques encourus par toute la plan√®te. Or, si Covid-19 est probablement d‚Äôorigine naturelle, rien ne nous dit que la prochaine pand√©mie le sera aussi. Il est peut-√™tre temps de r√©hausser les normes de s√©curit√© appliqu√©es actuellement en Chine, aux √âtats-Unis, et ailleurs‚Ä¶

Raoult. Et comme lors de l‚Äôaffaire Jessus, ce nouveau billet m√©lange faits av√©r√©s, accusations ad hominem, et ¬´preuves¬ª de fraude scientifique.

Comme souvent dans ce genre de situation, il y a les faits objectifs, les hypoth√®ses √† v√©rifier et les √©l√©ments de contexte qui contribuent √† noircir inutilement le tableau.
Je ne m‚Äôattarderai pas sur la seconde partie du billet de Schneider, qui accuse le Pr. Didier Raoult d‚Äô√™tre un tortionnaire n‚Äôh√©sitant pas √† d√©truire en public ses √©tudiants, un misogyne ayant tent√© d‚Äô√©touffer une affaire de harc√®lement sexuel au sein de son institut ou encore un climatosceptique de la premi√®re heure. Compte tenu de son ego surdimensionn√© et de sa propension √† d√©nigrer ses pairs, il n‚Äôest pas √©tonnant que le Pr. Mais si l‚Äôon veux √† tout prix tirer le portrait de l‚Äôhomme derri√®re le chercheur, il ne faudra pas oublier que l‚Äôon parle tout de m√™me d‚Äôun m√©decin qui a d√©di√© sa vie √† traiter des malades et √† faire avancer l‚Äôinfectiologie.
Au rang des hypoth√®ses √† v√©rifier, on compte un certain nombre d‚Äôaccusations graves de fraude scientifique li√©es √† certaines publications r√©centes cosign√©es par le Pr. Raoult. Mais d‚Äôune part, les manipulations d‚Äôimages et les erreurs de s√©quen√ßage dont il est question devront faire l‚Äôobjet d‚Äôune enqu√™te approfondie avant d‚Äô√™tre consid√©r√©es comme constituant une preuve de fraude. Et d‚Äôautre part, le Pr. Raoult n‚Äôest qu‚Äôauteur interm√©diaire sur la plupart de ces √©tudes: vu le nombre d√©mentiel d‚Äôarticles qu‚Äôil publie chaque ann√©e, il est tr√®s peu probable que ces fautes ‚Äî si elles sont av√©r√©es ‚Äî soient le r√©sultat d‚Äôune intervention directe de sa part.
A mon sens, cet empilement d‚Äôaccusations ressemble plus √† une chasse √† l‚Äôhomme qu‚Äô√† une critique scientifique, et il fait perdre de vue la question essentielle: faut-il ou non placer nos espoirs dans le traitement propos√© par le Pr. Triple-casquette et statistiques bancales
Avant d‚Äôentrer dans le vif du sujet, on grincera tout de m√™me des dents en remarquant que l‚Äô√©diteur-en-chef de la revue dans laquelle l‚Äôarticle a √©t√© publi√© n‚Äôest autre que Jean-Marc Rolain, qui est √©galement co-auteur et subalterne du Pr. Cela signifie que les ‚Äúreviewers‚Äù charg√©s de d√©celer d‚Äô√©ventuels probl√®mes m√©thodologiques n‚Äôen ont trouv√© aucun ou que leurs critiques n‚Äôont pas √©t√© entendues.

‚Ä¢ L‚Äôexistence possible (et probable) de biais dans la mani√®re dont les groupes de patients ont √©t√© constitu√©s. Cependant, les patients du groupe contr√¥le √©tant en moyenne plus jeunes et moins souvent de sexe masculin, cette absence de randomisation n‚Äôinvalide probablement pas √† elle seule les conclusions de l‚Äô√©tude.
‚Ä¢ Bien plus g√™nant, en revanche, l‚Äô√©quipe du Pr. Raoult a exclu a posteriori six patients du groupe ayant re√ßu le traitement actif. Ici le probl√®me est s√©rieux car au moins 4 de ces patients peuvent √™tre consid√©r√©s comme des √©checs th√©rapeutiques. Ne pas les inclure a donc pu fausser consid√©rablement les conclusions statistiques compte tenu de la taille r√©duite des √©chantillons test√©s.
‚Ä¢ Enfin et surtout, les auteurs du rapport et de nombreux autres scientifiques pointent l‚Äôabsence de donn√©es proprement cliniques sur l‚Äô√©volution des patients. L‚Äôunique variable consid√©r√©e est la charge virale, et il est donc exag√©r√© voire malhonn√™te de clamer haut et fort, sur la base de cette √©tude seule, que la combinaison chloroquine et azithromycine constitue un traitement contre la maladie. A ce jour, l‚Äôunique autre publication √©valuant l‚Äôefficacit√© de la chloroquine sugg√®re que celle-ci n‚Äôa aucun effet, prise isol√©ment, sur l‚Äô√©volution clinique. Il est donc possible que le traitement du Pr. Raoult rende le virus ind√©tectable dans les voies a√©riennes hautes (o√π se font les pr√©l√®vements), sans pour autant l‚Äô√©radiquer du reste de l‚Äôorganisme (et notamment des poumons).


Une strat√©gie m√©diatique d√©plorable
Ces critiques sugg√®rent que les recommandations du Pr. Raoult et de son √©quipe sont tr√®s pr√©matur√©es, et certaines irr√©gularit√©s mise en lumi√®res ‚Äî aussi bien dans le rapport des chercheurs anglais que sur Pubpeer ‚Äî sugg√®rent que les analyses sont loin des standards attendus compte tenu de la gravit√© de la crise et des orientations th√©rapeutiques qui pourraient √™tre prises en r√©ponse √† la campagne de communication men√©e par l‚Äôinfectiologue.
Bien entendu, l‚Äôurgence sanitaire justifie la publication rapide des r√©sultats scientifiques les plus prometteurs. L√† n‚Äôest pas la question. La question n‚Äôest pas non plus de savoir qui est au juste le Pr. Raoult. Ce qui importe √† l‚Äôheure actuelle, c‚Äôest que le d√©bat public puisse avoir lieu dans de bonnes conditions sans que quiconque n‚Äôutilise la crise pour se mettre sous le feu des projecteurs.
Il y a donc de quoi s‚Äôagacer des prises de position aussi explosives qu‚Äôimpudiques du Pr. Raoult, aussi prompt √† s‚Äôauto-congratuler qu‚Äô√† disqualifier le travail de ses pairs.
Et il y a de quoi d√©plorer, en miroir, le peu d‚Äôaudience obtenue par l‚ÄôAcad√©mie de m√©decine qui consid√®re que ‚Äúla lib√©ration par les pouvoirs publics de l‚Äôhydroxychloroquine pour les malades hospitalis√©s en d√©tresse respiratoire ne saurait √™tre une r√©ponse adapt√©e pour des patients dont la charge virale est, √† ce stade, le plus souvent inexistante et dont la maladie n‚Äôest plus une virose stricto sensu mais une d√©faillance pulmonaire‚Äù (communiqu√© officiel, ici).


Pour aller plus loin

En outre, le retour √† une vie sociale et professionnelle normale peut √™tre difficile, en particulier pour les personnels soignants et leur famille. Parmi les facteurs de risque, on retrouve √©videmment la fragilit√© financi√®re des foyers touch√©s, mais √©galement le manque d‚Äôinformation sur la dur√©e et les justifications du confinement qui contribuent √† un sentiment d‚Äôincertitude d√©l√©t√®re.

Des recommandations concr√®tes
Les auteurs de l‚Äô√©tude mettent en lumi√®re le r√¥le-cl√© jou√© par les pouvoirs publics, souvent d√©faillants dans leur gestion des personnes confin√©es. Contre toute attente, m√™me dans un pays aussi riche que le Canada, les livraisons de nourriture et de m√©dicaments furent mal g√©r√©es durant l‚Äô√©pid√©mie de SARS √† Toronto entre 2002 et 2004, et les indemnit√©s promises furent vers√©es avec beaucoup de retard. Il est donc essentiel que le gouvernement fran√ßais, apr√®s avoir impos√© le confinement et une v√©ritable quarantaine aux personnes pouvant avoir √©t√© infect√©es par Covid-19, assume ses responsabilit√©s.
En la mati√®re, l‚Äôarticle pr√©conise les mesures suivantes:
‚Ä¢ Les quarantaines strictes impos√©es aux personnes potentiellement contagieuses doivent √™tre limit√©es autant que possible √† la p√©riode d‚Äôincubation du virus.
‚Ä¢ Les pouvoirs publiques et les autorit√©s sanitaires doivent donner le maximum d‚Äôinformation possible sur la conduite √† tenir, sur les justifications et sur la dur√©e du confinement.
‚Ä¢ Les pouvoirs publics doivent s‚Äôassurer que les personnes confin√©es aient acc√®s aux ressources de bases, aussi bien au plan nutritionnel que sanitaire.
‚Ä¢ Faciliter la communication des personnes isol√©es avec le monde ext√©rieur et en particulier avec le milieu m√©dical qui doit assurer un suivi aussi r√©gulier que possible des sympt√¥mes physiologiques et psychologiques.
‚Ä¢ Porter une attention particuli√®re au personnel soignant, qui est en premi√®re ligne dans le combat contre le virus et qui constitue la population la plus susceptible de souffrir de s√©quelles psychologiques √† long-terme.
Au del√† de ces mesures de bon sens, les auteurs mettent en lumi√®re le manque de donn√©es disponibles, notamment en ce qui concerne les personnes souffrant d√©j√† de troubles psychologiques ou psychiatriques pour qui l‚Äôisolement pourrait √™tre particuli√®rement difficile √† vivre.


Vers une mobilisation des psychologues professionnels dans la lutte contre Covid-19?
Un effort de recherche consid√©rable para√Æt donc n√©cessaire aujourd‚Äôhui. En effet, contrairement aux √©pid√©mies r√©centes, ce sont des millions de personnes qui sont actuellement confin√©es chez elles. Tous les segments de la population sont concern√©s. On peut donc craindre qu‚Äôune saturation des services de soins psychologiques et psychiatriques accompagne la saturation des services de soins intensifs, √† l‚Äôimage de ce qu‚Äôil se passe en Chine.
A cet √©gard, une mobilisation massive et coordonn√©e des psychologues professionnels serait extr√™mement utile pour mieux contenir et √©valuer les cons√©quences √† court- et √† long-terme de cette strat√©gie de sant√© publique.
La mise en place de consultations √† distance subventionn√©es par l‚Äô√âtat est √©videmment indispensable, et la collaboration entre psychologues, psychiatres et chercheurs para√Æt souhaitable.
En ces temps sombres, la stabilit√© et la r√©silience de la soci√©t√© tout enti√®re d√©pend de notre capacit√© √† anticiper les cons√©quences de l‚Äô√©pid√©mie, et l‚Äôaspect psychologique de celle-ci n‚Äô√©chappe pas √† la r√®gle.

title: Could Covid-19 Have Originated on American Soil?
text:
The hypothesis of a laboratory leak, which until a few weeks ago was immediately classified as a conspiracy theory, is now being considered by almost the entire press as a plausible explanation for the emergence of Covid-19 (#1, #2, #3, #4). Unfortunately, by focusing exclusively on the Wuhan laboratory, the French media are playing into the hands of the Trump administration and seem to forget that such a leak could have occurred anywhere in the world.
As I mentioned in my previous post entitled ‚ÄúOrigins of the Pandemic: Why We Should Not Blame China‚Äù (#5), the Wuhan origin of the virus remains uncertain and the United States is also on the list of potential suspects if the laboratory leak hypothesis is retained. Indeed, like China, Americans are extremely active in research on bat coronaviruses. While Ralph Baric‚Äôs laboratory at the University of North Carolina is certainly the most publicized due to controversial experiments aimed at making these viruses more aggressive to humans (#6, #7), many other organizations are working on the subject. Beyond universities and pharmaceutical companies, coronaviruses have been studied for over ten years by the US military (more on this later) and by private entities like Ecohealth Alliance (#8, #9) ‚Äî specializing in the discovery of new bat viruses and having published more than fifty scientific articles on the subject since 2013 (#10).
Today, I propose to delve deeper into this American hypothesis, hoping it will help balance the debate, which dangerously leans towards a form of primary Atlanticism tinged with conspiracy theories. But I am well aware that this is a sensitive subject, whose discourse can easily be ‚Äúrecovered‚Äù to fuel other conspiracy theories. This post, therefore, cannot do without a preliminary warning.
The facts outlined below in chronological form should in no way be interpreted as a body of evidence. They merely illustrate a hypothesis among others, which needs to be formally tested. The temporal juxtaposition of events does not imply the existence of a causal link. It is also important to avoid being convinced by the multiplication of converging information, as these pieces of information have been chosen to support the plausibility of a particular hypothesis, and thus suffer from significant selection bias. Finally, and most importantly, we must not forget that hundreds of scientific publications suggest that the emergence of the virus is most likely natural and that human error is, on the contrary, improbable. We know that humans come into contact with bats on all continents, that animal-to-human transmissions are frequent, and we understand the general mechanisms governing this process.
I encourage readers attracted, like myself, to the examination of alternative scenarios to differentiate between the political stakes surrounding the hypothesis of a potential laboratory escape and the medical-scientific approach for whom this hypothesis is as improbable as it is useless in terms of combating the pandemic itself. This battle is being fought in the search for effective treatments and vaccines, which do not depend on the virus‚Äôs nationality.

Mid-July 2019: Unexplained Pneumonia Outbreak in Virginia
On July 11, 2019, a pneumonia outbreak occurred in a retirement home in Virginia, on the east coast of the United States (#11, #12). With 63 residents and 19 staff members infected (3 deaths), the event was serious enough to be reported to the Center for Disease Control (CDC), which oversees federal epidemiological surveillance. However, according to the Fairfax County report (#13), the CDC could not isolate the cause and only found the common cold virus in a minority of patients.
Other similar events occurred nearby, and Virginia health services reported between 16 and 19 local respiratory disease outbreaks during the summer of 2019 (#14, #15, #16), which is an abnormal toll for this small East Coast state.


August 2019: Start of the Vaping-Related Pneumonia Epidemic
On July 26, 2019, CNN was the first media outlet to report 8 cases of unexplained pneumonia among teenagers and young adults in Wisconsin, near Chicago (#17). The vaping hypothesis was suggested because the usual pneumonia-causing viruses or bacteria were not found. In the absence of medical history or exposure to a virulent pathogen, this disease is very rare among young people. On August 2, the CDC used its emergency information platform to send a document to American hospitals reporting severe respiratory illnesses possibly related to vaping (#18). On August 3, CNN published a second article reporting 14 cases in Wisconsin and Illinois (#19).
This marked the beginning of an ‚Äúepidemic‚Äù of vaping-related pneumonias, grouped under the term EVALI (E-cigarette or Vaping product use Associated Lung Injury). The term epidemic is used because the geographical clustering of cases and their temporal dynamics are evocative of a viral epidemic (#20). Indeed, the same exponential increase observed since the start of the pandemic can be seen, as evidenced by the study by Yulin Hswen and John Brownstein (#21, Boston Hospital).



Confirmed or suspected cases of vaping-related pneumonia (July 25 - September 20, 2019). Source: Yulin Hswen and John Brownstein, New England Journal of Medicine.


The clinical manifestations of EVALI are very similar to those of Covid-19, including fever, pain, gastrointestinal issues, difficulty breathing, and a course lasting ten to fifteen days. Lung x-rays reflect this similarity, with ‚Äúground-glass opacities‚Äù found in both diseases (#22, #23, #24). Although EVALI is not considered contagious unlike Covid-19, it should be noted that Covid-19‚Äôs very long incubation period makes detecting transmission chains much more difficult than for other viruses.
Studies quickly launched by the CDC suggested that EVALI might be caused by the presence of vitamin E in some vaping mixtures, especially those containing THC (#25, #26). However, according to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), this ingredient was found in only 50% of the products examined (#27), and the epidemic could not be associated with the appearance of a new product introduced to the market in the summer of 2019. Moreover, the existence of a causal link between vitamin E and pneumonia remains uncertain for methodological reasons.
As of December 19, 2019, there were already more than 2,500 cases and 54 deaths related to EVALI in the United States (#28). While the CDC published reassuring figures in January 2020 showing a sharp decline in the curve, the decrease observed from late September is probably due to two effects: the delay in reporting information to the federal level and the change in criteria defining the disease, which became stricter on September 18 (#29). However, the criteria used allow any pneumonia occurring up to 90 days after a vaping experience to be associated with EVALI, which is extremely flexible and allows the inclusion of many patients who vape only rarely. The point is not to identify Covid-19 with EVALI, nor to deny that EVALI exists as such, but simply to point out that epidemiological surveillance mechanisms may have malfunctioned due to the co-occurrence of two independent problems with overlapping clinical manifestations.


Late November: The Flu Season Begins Particularly Early in the United States
Following the vaping-associated pneumonia epidemic came the flu epidemic, well known for generating symptoms similar to Covid-19, including respiratory difficulties that can lead to pneumonia. In late November - early December 2019, many regions reported the early onset of flu-like symptoms and respiratory illnesses (#30, #31, #32, #33, #34, #35). Federal data indicates that the flu epidemic started almost a month earlier this year (#36) and that excess mortality was observed compared to previous years (#37).



Percentage of visits for flu-like symptoms late 2019, early 2020. Source: Center for Disease Control.


Unlike EVALI, the flu can be formally tested. However, looking closely at the data, the number of samples collected is tiny compared to the number of cases reported (hundreds out of hundreds of thousands of cases), and only 10 to 15% of samples show a flu virus infection (#38).
From the perspective of an American origin preceding the explosion of cases in Wuhan, it is conceivable that the EVALI and flu epidemics contributed to Covid-19 going unnoticed by the authorities.


January 2020: Official Arrival of Covid-19 on American Soil and Scandal Related to Defective Tests
On January 20, 2019, Covid-19 officially made its appearance on American soil (#40, #41). The CDC announced the first positive result. This institution being the only one authorized by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), all initial tests were conducted internally. But faced with growing demand, the CDC announced it would begin sending test kits to various hospitals across the country on January 27 and simultaneously put its protocol online (#42). A week later, the kits were finally sent in very limited quantities (about 200; #43, #44).
Unfortunately, as early as February 12, numerous press articles indicated that the kits in question were defective and their results would be uninterpretable (#45), a problem recognized the following day by the CDC, which announced it would send replacement kits (#46). Yet, two long weeks later, the United States had only tested 426 people, while South Korea had already tested 35,000 (#47).
At the time when Trump announced that the epidemic was ‚Äúunder control‚Äù and insisted in the media on defending the government‚Äôs actions as ‚Äúappropriate‚Äù (#48), controversy was growing in national laboratories and research institutes, which struggled to obtain the necessary authorization to produce their own tests. The detailed article in the New Yorker on this subject is eloquent: it was not until February 29 that the FDA authorized a laboratory other than the CDC to diagnose Covid-19, and these authorizations were initially given sparingly due to the slow administrative system (#49).


April 2020: Over 700,000 Americans Infected by the Virus and Unanswered Questions
Two months later, the United States is one of the nations most affected by the epidemic (#50). This catastrophic toll is partly explained by the superpower‚Äôs inability to develop an effective test before the end of February, even though the necessary technology has been used for twenty years in countless laboratories around the world (#51).
The numerous infection clusters that went unnoticed by the CDC obviously contributed to this rapid evolution. But given the detailed chronology above, one can legitimately wonder how long Covid-19 has been present on American soil. Is it possible that the epidemic began in the United States through short transmission chains, in Virginia and neighboring states, before disguising itself as a vaping-related pneumonia epidemic with clinical manifestations similar to Covid-19?
In theory, these questions could receive a positive answer if the suspected pneumonia cases mentioned above were retrospectively tested for Covid-19. It is even conceivable that the CDC questioned the link between the Covid-19 epidemic and the vaping-related pneumonia epidemic. However, if the test results performed at the beginning of the pandemic cannot be interpreted due to the technical errors that are now causing a scandal, this question may remain unanswered forever.
To insinuate that it might not be in the American administration‚Äôs interest to reveal such results would be to make an accusation without basis here. However, if we accept the hypothesis of an American origin, nothing prevents us from examining potential triggering events.
Of course, nothing excludes an animal-to-human transmission on American soil, as American bats also constitute ‚Äî like their African, European, or Chinese counterparts ‚Äî a reservoir of coronaviruses (#52, #53, #54). However, if the virus emerged naturally, it is much more plausible that the event occurred in China due to the proximity between Covid-19 and a bat coronavirus discovered on Chinese territory (the famous BatCov-RaTG13).
In other words, if we turn to the West, it makes sense to examine the possibility of human error, and in particular, the possibility of an incident involving the USAMRIID laboratories based at Fort Detrick (Maryland).


Back to August 2019: Sudden Closure of the Fort Detrick Laboratory
On August 2, 2019, the CDC ordered the sudden closure of the P3 and P4 laboratories at Fort Detrick in Maryland (#55), two weeks after the suspicious pneumonia outbreak that opened the above chronology. At Fort Detrick, located just 65 kilometers from the Greenspring retirement home, the US military conducts research on the world‚Äôs most dangerous infectious agents, including the plague bacillus and the Ebola virus. Many American media outlets reported this information and reminded readers that Fort Detrick is known not only for its historical role in American bioweapon programs but also for its probable involvement in the anthrax-contaminated letters scandal in September 2001 (#56, #57, #58).
The problem detected by the authorities was apparently multifactorial, without a clear indication of which factor led to the site‚Äôs closure: some procedures did not meet established standards, some personnel had not received adequate training, and a flaw was discovered in the water decontamination system. This flaw apparently dated back to May 2018, when floods damaged the institute‚Äôs water circuit (#59), meaning more than a year of research was conducted under defective safety conditions.



USAMRIID Research Center at Fort Detrick. Source: Wikimedia Commons.


Without going into detail, it should also be noted that these anomalies occurred in a very particular context: a legal battle between Battelle Memorial Institute ‚Äî the private company operating the site ‚Äî and Laulima Government Solutions regarding the management of the site‚Äôs decontamination process (see the US government‚Äôs decision in this dispute: #60). In October 2019, Laulima, which proposed a $150 million project against $190 million for Battelle, ultimately won and became responsible for decontamination, despite apparently limited experience in this area. It may seem surprising that a laboratory of such strategic importance to the US military is managed by a private company subject to profitability imperatives, but this is actually common in the United States. Battelle alone directly manages 9 major research centers on American soil (#61). The Fort Detrick center is managed by one of its subsidiaries, Tunnel Government Services (#62).
Although coronaviruses are not Fort Detrick‚Äôs specialty, it is known that some research has recently focused on the MERS coronavirus (see this 2018 publication, #63). It is also known that this laboratory has used advanced technology called CRISPR-Cas9 to selectively extract certain genetic sequences from several viruses, including Ebola (#64). And not just any sequences. Indeed, the objective of the article in question was to extract sequences coding for a ‚Äúfurin cleavage site‚Äù which is also involved in Covid-19‚Äôs virulence and whose presence in the Covid-19 genome is considered ‚Äúunexpected‚Äù by researchers (#65, #66, #67).
Should we believe, based on this information, that Covid-19 resulted from human error at Fort Detrick and silently spread in the United States before mutating in Wuhan to eventually cause the pandemic we are facing?
No.¬†We should continue to associate a very low probability with this hypothesis and prioritize the overwhelming consensus among researchers that the virus emerged naturally in China, following direct contamination of a human by a bat or an intermediate animal yet to be discovered.
At most, we can use the information reported here to avoid being blindly drawn into the strategy of Trump, Mike Pompeo, Fox News, and to a lesser extent Emmanuel Macron or other Western leaders, who are quick to insinuate that China is morally responsible for the pandemic (#68, #69, #70, #71).
According to a 2018 report to the US Congress (#72), the management of P3 and P4 laboratories is far from flawless in the United States. Source of scandals in the past, these laboratories are both older and more numerous than in China. Their operation by private companies raises doubts about their reliability in a context of cost reduction and economic difficulties exacerbated by Trump‚Äôs arrival in power (#73).
While virus research is obviously necessary, many experts fear that some P3 and P4 laboratories are ticking time bombs (#80, #81, #82). The Covid-19 pandemic and the suspicions it raises could thus be an opportunity for collective awareness: the gradual proliferation of these laboratories mathematically increases the risks faced by the entire planet. If Covid-19 is probably of natural origin, nothing tells us that the next pandemic will be as well. It may be time to raise the safety standards currently applied in China, the United States, and elsewhere‚Ä¶

title: Is Trump‚Äôs Victory a Defeat for Intelligence?
text:
Entitled ‚ÄúCognitive Ability and Authoritarianism: Understanding Support for Trump and Clinton,‚Äù the article by Becky Choma and Yaniv Hanoch describes the complex relationship between cognitive ability and support for the new American president, Donald Trump.
Specifically, the researchers invited 400 American voters to take an IQ test (very abbreviated, hence the vague term ‚Äúcognitive ability‚Äù) and a series of questionnaires. Among these were questions about voting intentions and pro-Trump opinions, as well as two personality scales known as SDO (Social Dominance Orientation) and RWA (Right-Wing Authoritarianism).
The SDO is frequently used in psychology to assess the tendency to legitimize hierarchical relationships within societies (e.g., men-women, whites-minorities, etc.). The RWA is used to evaluate the tendency to desire an authoritarian, conservative government that upholds traditional, particularly religious, values.

The Indirect Link Between Trumpism and Intelligence
While the results indicate there is no direct link between intelligence and voting for Trump, they do highlight an indirect link.
A path analysis (PDF) revealed that lower cognitive ability is, on average, associated with a stronger legitimization of existing dominance relationships (SDO) and a stronger attraction to authoritarian and traditionalist policies (RWA). Since these two scales have a powerful impact on adherence to Trump‚Äôs theses (and more generally to conservative theses), intelligence likely played an indirect role in the outcome of the American presidential election.
In summary, individuals with lower IQs were, on average, more likely to vote for Trump due to increased sensitivity to discourses that propose reinforcing the domination of certain social groups over others, based on religious or racial distinctions. It would have been interesting to know if these same voters also readily accept authority relationships based on intellectual or academic distinctions, but the researchers did not address this question.



Summary of the study published in the Journal of Personality and Individual Differences on 11/3/2016. Plus symbols (+) denote a positive association between variables, minus symbols (-) denote a negative association.


Obviously, since the study was conducted online and the evaluation of intelligence remains very rudimentary, its results should be interpreted with caution. Moreover, although statistically significant, the effect explains only a small portion of the variance in voting intentions (less than 5%). Finally, the mechanism linking intelligence and political opinions could be different in the United States and France.
That said, the researchers accounted for the influence of many other variables on the result, which is a strength. For example, their data show that being older or wealthier facilitates voting for Trump, while being more educated facilitates voting for Clinton, but accounting for these demographic factors does not change the main effect of the study: the indirect link ‚Äúintelligence ‚Üí SDO/RWA ‚Üí vote Trump‚Äù remains.


A Struggle for Simplicity
Is Choma and Hanoch‚Äôs study relevant for countering the rise of far-right ideas in French society?
Perhaps. Indeed, if the difficulty in understanding the world we live in is the reason for communal retreat and authoritarian desire, it seems essential for the (true) left to clearly articulate its vision of the world and its project for the future. In other words, to simplify its message without falling into simplism and without betraying itself.
Some might argue that it is technically impossible to be simpler than the primary Manichaeism of a Trump or a Le Pen.
But this is not necessarily true. After all, far-right discourses rely on constructing a binary world distinguishing them and us, while internationalist left has always pursued the idea of a unitary world, that of humanity.
Putting this human at the forefront and showing the difficulty of establishing a sensible and non-arbitrary demarcation between them and us could ultimately shift the simplicity to the other side.

title: Social Inequalities: The Cognitive Profile of Those Who Don‚Äôt Care.
text:
As anticipated in the government‚Äôs schedule, Euro 2016, the Olympics, and the August sun were enough to relegate social issues to the background. It is clear that idealists and the outraged have lost a battle. Nuit Debout may have fizzled out, but should we consider the occupations of public spaces and spring protests as another futile effort? The answer depends on our ability to learn and return stronger in the autumn, and to be more aware when it‚Äôs time to elect a new leader.
There is at least one thing this major social movement, punctuated by the physical violence of the CRS and the moral violence of the 49-3, has taught us: there exists in France a system of social domination so powerful and self-assured that its representatives no longer even pretend to care about democracy.
Anyone is free to believe that the most harmful person to our country is named Mohamed and drives refrigerated trucks, or that he is named Manuel and is driving France into the abyss. For an avoidable massacre on the Promenade des Anglais, how many avoidable deaths occur in the beds of our underfunded hospitals?

title: Social Inequalities: The Cognitive Profile of Those Who Don‚Äôt Care.
text:
Unmasking
From Juncker to Valls, including Hollande and Sarkozy, the indifference of the dominant political classes towards the inequalities generated by ultra-liberal logic is more evident than ever. These reforms, led by a socialist government elected to implement the opposite policy, prove that this indifference is not a matter of political color but is rooted in the very structures of the Fifth Republic.
Even the speeches of a brilliant polymath like Fr√©d√©ric Lordon remain on the periphery of certain crucial questions. The will of the citizen is hindered by a structural problem, certainly, but before being implemented by institutions, any policy is first decided by individuals. Thus, to the institutional structures cherished by Lordon, we must add the psychological or cultural structures once dear to Foucault and L√©vi-Strauss.
Since a politician like Manuel Valls‚Äôs policies clearly do not rely on popular will or what he forgot to learn in his History degree, they likely stem from personal motivations and influences that we need to better understand.
Unfortunately, as unique as he may be, the Prime Minister is just one embodiment of the malady that afflicts our society from the top. He is a product of his time‚Äîa highly successful one, but replaceable. Cut off his head, and a hundred more will grow. The problem lies not with the individuals themselves but with the system that shapes and selects them.
To inscribe the struggle for democracy and social justice in the long term, beyond football and weather contingencies, beyond the constant media noise, it is essential to understand the psychological dynamics of the dominant class.
‚ÄúHe who knows his enemy as he knows himself will not be defeated in a hundred battles. He who knows himself but not the enemy will win one and lose one. He who knows neither his enemy nor himself is always in danger.‚Äù ‚Äî Sun Tzu, The Art of War

title: Social Inequalities: The Cognitive Profile of Those Who Don‚Äôt Care.
text:
Are the Gauls still indomitable?
Social dominance is a phenomenon that emerges spontaneously through competition among individuals of the same species. This competition is inevitable when living conditions and resources deteriorate, and humans are certainly no exception. It is a natural principle that has always structured human societies and deeply shaped how our brains and bodies function. In humans, the thirst for dominance persists well beyond the satisfaction of biological needs, hence the ancient proverb ‚Äúman is a wolf to man.‚Äù
However, dominance hierarchies are never irreversible. As √âtienne de la Bo√©tie wrote in his timeless Discourse on Voluntary Servitude nearly five centuries ago, they exist only as long as men tolerate being kept in subordination. Contemporary primatologists like Bernstein and Rowell echo this, considering that a dominance relationship is established only when an individual or group of individuals ceases to defend their rights or pursue their aspirations after being ‚Äúdefeated‚Äù by another individual or group.
In other words, the psychological dynamics at work in the middle and lower classes play an equally important role in maintaining the status quo we deplore. Although their symptoms differ, Manuel and Mohamed are together victims of the same alienating and deadly logic: that of dominance and subordination, which must be distinguished from other hierarchical constructions like prestige or leadership.

title: Social Inequalities: The Cognitive Profile of Those Who Don‚Äôt Care.
section: The Desire for Dominance and Its Justification
text:
The Desire for Dominance and Its Justification
Today, a professor at Harvard, Jim Sidanius initiated a resurgence of research on social dominance in humans in the early 2000s. In his most cited work, Social Dominance: An Intergroup Theory of Social Hierarchy and Oppression, he describes how human societies are structured around the problem of dominance‚Äîhow the behaviors and beliefs of those who reinforce or seek to legitimize dominance interact with those who seek to combat and deconstruct it. His conclusions are partly based on the analysis of the SDO scale (Social Dominance Orientation), which measures the propensity to justify social inequalities and desire a stable hierarchical order. Respondents indicate their agreement (from 1, not at all, to 7, completely) with about fifteen statements such as:

Some people are simply inferior to others.
To get ahead in life, it is sometimes necessary to step on others.
The country would be better off if we cared less about social inequalities.
It is probably a good thing that certain groups are at the top and others are at the bottom.
Lower groups should stay in their place.

Etc., etc. (PDF)
During my own research on social hierarchies and the brain (PDF), I was stunned by the results of young French and Swiss students on this questionnaire and by the extremely high scores observed in some. My naivety took a hit, my optimism too, and this awareness led to many readings and reflections.
Historically, the SDO scale is akin to the ‚Äù F scale‚Äù developed in 1947 by philosopher Theodor Adorno to measure the aspiration to fascism in Western societies. While the F scale is no longer widely used today, scientific literature on SDO expands each year (about 6000 articles refer to it).

title: Social Inequalities: The Cognitive Profile of Those Who Don‚Äôt Care.
section: A Clinical Picture Mixing Racism, Sexism, Lack of Empathy, and Environmental Indifference
text:
A Clinical Picture Mixing Racism, Sexism, Lack of Empathy, and Environmental Indifference
Firstly, individuals scoring high on the SDO scale are on average more racist and sexist than others (PDF). The link between SDO and racism persists among individuals from minority ethnicities, just as the link between SDO and sexism persists among women. Thus, even though white men generally score higher (the so-called invariance hypothesis; PDF), the psychological mechanisms of dominance are active in all members of our society.
Additionally, Sandra Duarte, Michel Dambrun, and Serge Guimond‚ÄîFrench researchers specializing in SDO‚Äîhave shown that the relationship between legitimizing social hierarchies and sexist or racist prejudices persists even when analyses are adjusted for left-right political positioning (PDF). In other words, the tool captures a phenomenon that transcends our traditional political categories.
More interestingly, individuals with high SDO also tend to experience less empathy, defined as ‚Äúthe ability to put oneself in another‚Äôs shoes and perceive what they feel.‚Äù This is particularly true when the other belongs to a different social group (an exogroup; PDF). Since the absence of empathy and SDO mutually reinforce over time (PDF), one cannot help but think of the consequences of Manuel Valls‚Äôs recent remarks that ‚Äù explaining jihadism is already excusing it.‚Äù
Finally, it has recently been demonstrated that those who legitimize dominance relations between individuals and groups are also more likely to legitimize human dominance over other living species. This is evidenced by a large study from 2013 showing that SDO clearly correlates with numerous ‚Äúenvironmental attitudes‚Äù: individuals or populations scoring high on this scale are less likely to believe in human-caused climate change and promote a more utilitarian relationship with nature. If Donald Trump knows something about this, the socialists governing us are no less responsible, as evidenced by the death of R√©mi Fraisse at the Sievens dam or their obstinacy in the Notre-Dame-des-Landes case.

title: Social Inequalities: The Cognitive Profile of Those Who Don‚Äôt Care.
text:
The ‚ÄúLegitimizing Myths‚Äù
The effects mentioned here are not exhaustive, but they help us understand why sexism, racism, lack of empathy, and environmental indifference often go hand in hand: there is an underlying belief in all these attitudes that social inequalities and dominance relations are natural or even desirable. These are known as legitimizing myths.
Today, the most powerful of these myths is probably that of meritocracy, which stipulates that the dominant ‚Äúdeserve‚Äù their position of power and the advantages that come with it, notwithstanding the disintegration of social mobility. But there are others, more insidious, such as adherence to social Darwinism (the idea that society will improve if the strongest have power), the naturalization of social hierarchies (the idea that some are genetically programmed to dominate and others to obey), or cultural representations like ‚Äúreligiosity is a more primitive attitude than atheism,‚Äù ‚Äúegalitarianism is a utopia,‚Äù ‚Äútrue democracy is impossible in the current world,‚Äù ‚Äúpeople are stupid,‚Äù etc., etc.
At the societal level and in the long term, the frequency and intensity of high SDO signs among our leaders should alert us to the very low ideological and intellectual diversity of the political class. This uniformity results primarily from the endogamy within the ruling classes (see Ghettos du Gotha, by Monique Pin√ßon-Charlot and Michel Pin√ßon; PDF). Unfortunately, in the absence of a revolution renewing the entire political class, only republican education and evolving mentalities can combat this vicious circle.

title: Social Inequalities: The Cognitive Profile of Those Who Don‚Äôt Care.
text:
What to Do?
To move forward, we must first stop turning away from politics because current politicians no longer represent us. As philosopher Herbert Marcuse writes, ‚Äúthe ability to freely elect masters does not abolish either masters or slaves,‚Äù but abstaining from voting and dismissing this issue that concerns us all leaves the way open for the most mediocre masters and embraces kakistocracy.
Raising awareness of the importance of environmental and developmental factors that reinforce existing social hierarchies and/or facilitate social submission is also crucial. A study in France demonstrated the link between SDO and belief in genetic determinism of behavior, while understanding basic sociological principles can reduce scores (PDF). To fill these gaps, reading books by Jared Diamond such as Guns, Germs, and Steel (Pulitzer Prize 1998) or the shorter and magnificent essay by Henri Laborit Praise of Flight, which was also adapted into a film in Alain Resnais‚Äôs My American Uncle (watch for free on YouTube), is highly recommended.
The psychological mechanisms that allow brash individuals like Manuel Valls to seduce France are actually at work in each of us. Among them, Leon Festinger‚Äôs famous ‚Äù cognitive dissonance‚Äú‚Äîwhereby our beliefs adjust a posteriori to the actions we take‚Äîfeatures prominently. To grasp the essence of this idea, a concrete example can be useful.
A deserving and well-intentioned graduate of a prestigious school enters a large company. After cutting his teeth on a few unimportant projects, he quickly climbs the ladder and soon finds himself forced to make decisions contrary to his initial value system, whether to keep his job or advance his career. Laying off productive elements, speculating on raw materials, avoiding corporate taxes, etc.: so many decisions that‚Äîwhile delighting his shareholders‚Äîundoubtedly exacerbate the social inequalities he might have denounced in high school.
This tension‚Äîor dissonance‚Äîbetween our values and behaviors results in a certain mental and emotional discomfort that calls for either modifying the behaviors in question (e.g., resigning) or modifying the values causing the guilt and discomfort. We frequently observe a shift in attitude toward social hierarchy, somewhere between ages 25 and 40, such that once-condemned dominance relationships are gradually considered legitimate and natural. There is a reversal in the relationship between belief and action that few individuals are willing to acknowledge, although the phenomenon is universally recognized by psychologists and applies equally to those who rise in political, academic, or financial spheres.
Of course, this transition is not without doubts, but being usually accompanied by a refocusing of the social reference group, it generally comes to fruition. The lure of gain and desire for material comfort also play a crucial role, compensating for submission to the system as a whole.
Fighting for a fairer society thus requires the courage to argue with those who contribute to injustice without necessarily realizing it. And then it requires the intelligence to reconcile. If we want to prevent the inner conflicts caused by hierarchical success from systematically resolving by increased legitimization of existing dominance relations, it is essential to maintain communication with those whose fingers are caught in the gears.

title: The ‚ÄòBrain Behind the Attacks‚Äô Taken Literally
text:
Every year, new words and expressions are born or revived in a public debate constantly stirred by the evolution of techniques and societies. Language exerts considerable, often implicit, influence on the formation of opinions, leading to an ongoing need to clarify its meaning and measure its impact.
Following the killings in France in 2015, an expression has become an almost indispensable term to denote our public enemy number one: the ‚Äòbrain behind the attacks,‚Äô this depersonalized and multifaceted threat that thrives at times in Salafist mosques, at other times in the suburbs of Saint-Denis, and at other times in Syria.
Adopted by most of the media and numerous politicians, the ‚Äòbrain behind the attacks‚Äô is one of those ready-made expressions that primarily reflect the difficulty, if not the abandonment, of thinking about terrorism beyond clich√©s and misleading rhetoric.

title: The ‚ÄòBrain Behind the Attacks‚Äô Taken Literally
text:
A Brain for Ten Terrorists?
Taken literally, searching relentlessly for the brain behind attacks committed by a dozen individuals is akin to denying the existence of a unique psychology in those who acted. It reduces these suicide bombers to puppets whose brains are washed by an occult intelligence, external to our society and foreign to our culture. Dangerous due to its implicit nature, this representation of the situation is problematic at a time when we seek to deradicalize and thus understand the tiny fraction of French youth inclined toward ‚Äòminor jihad‚Äô.
Yet there are reasons for hope. Over the past decade, some researchers have rigorously studied the determinants of terrorist violence. Simultaneously, neurobiologists and psychologists have made significant progress in understanding violent and antisocial behaviors. It is urgent that this knowledge enter the public debate, be considered by institutions, and be subject to serious investigation. This is also the aim of the call published on November 18, 2015 by Alain Fuchs, president of CNRS.

title: The ‚ÄòBrain Behind the Attacks‚Äô Taken Literally
section: Is the ‚ÄòBrain Behind the Attacks‚Äô a ‚ÄòSick Brain‚Äô?
text:
Is the ‚ÄòBrain Behind the Attacks‚Äô a ‚ÄòSick Brain‚Äô?
Although it is morally justifiable and understandable, the lexicon of madness and alienation (‚Äòmadmen‚Äô, ‚Äòmonsters‚Äô, ‚Äòsick‚Äô, etc.) used to describe terrorists is rarely justified clinically. Indeed, numerous retrospective studies on IRA (Ireland), ETA (Basque Country), or Al-Qaeda fighters show that terrorists‚Äîwhether Islamist or not‚Äîare most often within the ‚Äònormal distribution‚Äô concerning psychiatric pathologies, social origin, or education [PDF]. In other words, there is no psychiatric, psychological, or socio-economic profile that is typical of a suicide terrorist.
Established and accepted in a report submitted to the U.S. Congress as early as 1999 [PDF, page 40], this observation has also been discussed in the prestigious journal Science [PDF, PDF] under the impetus of Scott Atran. A pioneer in terrorism research, this Franco-American anthropologist also reminds us that the ‚Äòsuccess‚Äô associated with jihadist engagement on Twitter or Facebook constitutes a motivation as simple as it is powerful for martyr candidates, sensitive to the respect and admiration aroused in some by their morbid project (see Atran‚Äôs intervention to the UN Security Council, in English, and the French report associated with it).

A Paradoxical Altruism
Psychologically, suicide bombing is more akin to what researchers call ‚Äòaltruistic punishment‚Äô than to the murderous insanity responsible for the numerous shootings observed in the United States. The latter is often linked to a pre-existing mental pathology, which explains Barack Obama‚Äôs efforts to strengthen gun control for individuals suffering from psychiatric illnesses. In contrast, altruistic punishment involves incurring a cost to restore a social norm (of cooperation or otherwise) that one considers more significant than personal interest. The support of other group members and the role of social norms play an important role in such behaviors.
Thus, whether terrorists aspire to Sharia or democratic sovereignty in Islamic lands makes little difference, as the support (real or presumed) of the social group to which they identify seems to be the primary cause of their actions. This is also why bidirectional exchange between Arab-Muslim and Judeo-Christian cultures is the first remedy against terrorism. Symbolized by the opening of synagogues, churches, and mosques or by the tolerance of religious symbols such as the kippah, the cross, and the veil, the construction of a sense of belonging to French society heavily depends on citizens‚Äô ability to understand the emotions and moral feelings driving others beyond their usual social circle.
Although religious affiliation plays a crucial role since it overrides national belonging in the jihadists‚Äô imagination, research shows that they are not born or raised in more religious environments than average [PDF]. A study conducted in Palestine even suggests that despite its ability to segment humanity into communities of beliefs, religious sentiment itself does not predispose one to view terrorism as a morally just cause.



The trolley problem, widely used to study moral decision-making


Adapting the famous ‚Äòtrolley problem‚Äô, researchers asked over 1000 young people whether it would be just to kill a Palestinian to save five Israelis or five Palestinians. The first group was asked to decide directly on the best course of action. The second group was asked which decision God would approve of the most. Contrary to the belief that religious beliefs are the epicenter of inter-ethnic violence, the second group was clearly more inclined than the first to sacrifice the Palestinian man to save Israeli lives‚Ä¶

title: The ‚ÄòBrain Behind the Attacks‚Äô Taken Literally
section: Can Violent Deviations Be Prevented Using Neuroscience?
text:
Can Violent Deviations Be Prevented Using Neuroscience?
If the terrorist is distinguished neither by their mental state, religiosity, education level, nor beliefs, how can we initiate neurobiological reflection? Let‚Äôs perhaps start with what makes a jihadist a criminal: premeditated violence and the act itself.
Scientifically, premeditated violence corresponds to proactive aggression, as opposed to reactive aggression. The causes and consequences of these two phenomena are very different. In 2015, a study conducted with over 250 adolescents showed that proactive violence might reflect a desire to attain high social status, while reactive violence would denote a low social status [PDF]. Moreover, while proactive violence is not or is only slightly dependent on circulating cortisol levels (the stress hormone), reactive violence is strongly dependent on them. Finally, proactive aggression results more from a difficulty in experiencing emotions, while reactive aggression stems from an inability to regulate these emotions.
At the cerebral level, these findings translate in proactive violent individuals as hypo-reactivity of a central structure for emotions, the amygdala. In reactive violent individuals, on the other hand, there is an observed hyper-reactivity of the same structure. Pursuing a promising research avenue, a research group even showed that mild electrical stimulation of the anterior prefrontal cortex reduced levels of proactive aggression but had no effect on levels of reactive aggression.



The amygdala, a key structure for emotions - Anatomography/Wikimedia Commons/CC


Given that stimulation of the anterior prefrontal cortex also modifies how individuals perceive dominance relationships with others, these results may reinforce the link between proactive violence and the quest for social status (see also the thesis defended by the author of this blog, PDF, pp.¬†241-246).
Will it one day be possible to prevent deviations by treating perpetrators of violent acts early using this technique? Clinical trials may answer this question in the next two decades. In the meantime, it is important to remember that the visibility of laboratory studies is limited, as the most ‚Äòviolent‚Äô experimental protocols use only small, low-intensity electric shocks with no consequences.

title: The ‚ÄòBrain Behind the Attacks‚Äô Taken Literally
text:
Syndrome E, Amphetamines, and Psychopathy
Nearly 20 years ago, neuroscientist Itzhak Fried already suggested that individuals capable of killing coldly stand out less for dysfunctional reasoning than for a ‚Äòcognitive fracture‚Äô between emotional and decision-making processes [PDF]. This fracture would lead to what Fried called ‚ÄòSyndrome E,‚Äô related to psychopathy, which combines a lack of empathy with various emotional changes.
Moreover, without profoundly altering free will or intent as some widespread fantasy might suggest, cocaine and amphetamines used by some jihadists can nevertheless facilitate the act and composure. Prior to the act itself, because they affect the dopaminergic system and alter the activities of the amygdala, these psychostimulants somewhat mimic psychopathy and induce significant narcissism, excessive self-confidence, and heightened sensitivity to issues of social dominance. The encounter with these substances may therefore play a role in personality changes that precede or accompany radicalization.

title: The ‚ÄòBrain Behind the Attacks‚Äô Taken Literally
text:
Conclusion
In conclusion, we hope to have demonstrated that research into the causes of terrorism, at both the individual and social group levels, is feasible, desirable, and that its findings sometimes directly oppose certain preconceived ideas about the phenomenon. This is why the notion that the only brains that matter are those we have yet to kill or imprison is particularly deadly.
By focusing our attention on this elusive ‚Äòbrain behind the attacks‚Äô that supposedly hops between the bombs of our Rafales, we lose sight of the essential: the causes that led some French people to sacrifice their lives to punish the people they are supposed to belong to. Just like the real-fake ‚Äòclosure of borders‚Äô enacted and then canceled by Fran√ßois Hollande on the evening of November 13, or the absurd debate on ‚Äònationality revocation,‚Äô the hunt for the ‚Äòbrain behind the attacks‚Äô fits into a subtle game of semantic shifts that likely serve the electoral ambitions of some but also oppose intelligent counter-terrorism efforts.

title: Didier Raoult Accused of Scientific Fraud: What Should We Believe?
text:
Since the beginning of the Covid-19 crisis, Professor Didier Raoult has established himself as an essential figure in the public debate through forceful statements and extensive interviews.
Unsurprisingly, the publication of the results of his study evaluating the effectiveness of a treatment combining chloroquine and azithromycin received significant media attention. Given Professor Raoult‚Äôs controversial reputation and the sensitive nature of the study, it is not surprising that the scientific community also scrutinized the results with a particularly critical eye.
Approved on March 6, submitted on March 16, and published on March 20, this study is currently the subject of accusations of negligence or even scientific fraud by several researchers and science journalists. Among them, the tenacious Leonid Schneider ‚Äî who was already at the origin of the Catherine Jessus case in 2017 ‚Äî published a particularly harsh blog post against Professor Raoult. As in the Jessus case, this new post mixes proven facts, ad hominem attacks, and ‚Äúevidence‚Äù of scientific fraud.
In the face of what can only be called a torrent of mud, what should we believe?

Personal Attacks, Fraud Accusations, and Methodological Criticisms
As is often the case in such situations, there are objective facts, hypotheses to verify, and contextual elements that contribute to painting an unnecessarily dark picture.
I will not dwell on the second part of Schneider‚Äôs post, which accuses Professor Didier Raoult of being a torturer who does not hesitate to publicly humiliate his students, a misogynist who tried to cover up a sexual harassment case within his institute, and an early climate change skeptic. Given his overinflated ego and his tendency to denigrate his peers, it is not surprising that Professor Raoult has made many enemies, and it is not for me to judge the veracity of the facts presented, as concerning as they appear. But if we want to portray the man behind the researcher, we must not forget that we are still talking about a doctor who has dedicated his life to treating patients and advancing infectiology.
Among the hypotheses to be verified are several serious accusations of scientific fraud related to recent publications co-signed by Professor Raoult. However, image manipulations and sequencing errors will need to be thoroughly investigated before being considered as proof of fraud. Additionally, Professor Raoult is only an intermediate author on most of these studies: given the enormous number of articles he publishes each year, it is highly unlikely that these errors ‚Äî if proven ‚Äî are the result of direct intervention on his part.
In my opinion, this accumulation of accusations looks more like a witch hunt than scientific criticism, and it obscures the essential question: should we place our hopes in the treatment proposed by Professor Didier Raoult? Here, it is no longer the statements and insinuations of Leonid Schneider that need to be examined, but the facts highlighted by other active researchers.


Triple Hats and Flawed Statistics
Before diving into the heart of the matter, it is worth noting with some discomfort that the editor-in-chief of the journal where the article was published is none other than Jean-Marc Rolain, who is also a co-author and subordinate of Professor Raoult at the IHU M√©diterran√©e. Such triple roles are generally frowned upon in the academic world because it becomes difficult to believe in an impartial and unbiased evaluation of the scientific quality of the work reported.
Most of the criticisms have been posted on the site Pubpeer (a platform for post-publication peer review) or on MedRxiv (a preprint server for health sciences). However, one should first look at the very concise report posted by three British researchers on the site Zenodo. Proof of the attention it garnered, this report was downloaded over 18,000 times in five days.
The report‚Äôs authors first indicate that the paper underwent virtually no modifications between its posting on MedRxiv and its ‚Äúofficial‚Äù publication in Jean-Marc Rolain‚Äôs journal. This means that the reviewers responsible for identifying any methodological issues found none, or their criticisms were ignored.
However, the criticisms are numerous and often legitimate:
‚Ä¢ The statistical analyses reported in the paper are flawed because age and symptom differences between the tested groups were not accounted for. That said, a reanalyis of the data shows that the main effects hold when these variables are considered.
‚Ä¢ The possible (and likely) existence of biases in how patient groups were constituted. Thus, the control group patients (i.e., without treatment) were not all treated by Professor Raoult‚Äôs institute, unlike the patients receiving chloroquine. However, since the control group patients were on average younger and less often male, this lack of randomization probably does not invalidate the study‚Äôs conclusions on its own.
‚Ä¢ More problematic is that Professor Raoult‚Äôs team excluded six patients from the treatment group post hoc. Among them, one death, three patients admitted to intensive care, one patient with nausea, and one patient who ‚Äúleft the hospital.‚Äù This is serious because at least four of these patients can be considered therapeutic failures. Excluding them could have significantly skewed the statistical conclusions given the small sample sizes tested.
‚Ä¢ Finally, and most importantly, the report‚Äôs authors and many other scientists point to the absence of proper clinical data on patient outcomes. The only variable considered is viral load, so it is exaggerated and even dishonest to loudly proclaim, based on this study alone, that the combination of chloroquine and azithromycin constitutes a treatment for the disease. To date, the only other publication evaluating chloroquine‚Äôs effectiveness suggests that it has no effect, taken alone, on clinical outcomes. It is therefore possible that Professor Raoult‚Äôs treatment makes the virus undetectable in the upper airways (where the samples are taken) without eradicating it from the rest of the body (notably the lungs).


A Deplorable Media Strategy
These criticisms suggest that Professor Raoult and his team‚Äôs recommendations are very premature, and certain irregularities highlighted ‚Äî both in the British researchers‚Äô report and on Pubpeer ‚Äî suggest that the analyses fall far short of the standards expected given the severity of the crisis and the therapeutic directions that might be taken in response to the infectious disease specialist‚Äôs media campaign.
Of course, the health emergency justifies the rapid publication of the most promising scientific results. That is not the question. Nor is it a question of who Professor Raoult really is. What matters now is that the public debate can take place in good conditions without anyone using the crisis to put themselves in the spotlight.
There is thus reason to be annoyed by Professor Raoult‚Äôs explosive and immodest positions, as he is quick to self-congratulate and disqualify the work of his peers.
And there is reason to lament, conversely, the little attention received by the Academy of Medicine, which considers that ‚Äúthe public release of hydroxychloroquine for hospitalized patients in respiratory distress is not an appropriate response for patients whose viral load is, at this stage, mostly nonexistent and whose illness is no longer a strictly viral disease but a pulmonary failure‚Äù (official statement, here).


Further Reading
Analysis of the latest paper published on Saturday, March 28, by Professor Raoult‚Äôs team, still inconclusive despite the inclusion of a larger number of patients.
