title: Towards Self-Assessment and Horizontal Resource Control in Academia?
text:
Recently, a group of French researchers published an op-ed in Le Monde announcing their collective intention to apply for the presidency of the HCERES, France‚Äôs highest public authority for regulating and guiding research. This initiative, notably driven by rogueESR, has garnered over 5000 supports, including mine.
Responsible for evaluating all research laboratories in France, the HCERES and its predecessor, the AERES, have accompanied‚Äîand often encouraged‚Äîthe transformation of the French scientific landscape since 2006. Indeed, this ‚ÄúHigh Committee for the Evaluation of Research and Higher Education‚Äù is historically linked to the creation of the ANR (National Research Agency), which shifted French research toward an Anglo-Saxon ‚Äúproject-based‚Äù funding system in 2005.

A System Under Critique for 15 Years
This significant structural reform has provoked much discussion and exertion over the past 15 years. Indeed, it involves researchers dedicating a significant portion of their time to drafting funding applications that have little chance of success. Despite slight improvements since 2015, the success rate remains around 15%, with many agreeing that the time lost writing and evaluating these funding applications is largely counterproductive, both scientifically and economically, given the ANR‚Äôs enormous operational costs.
In this context, the op-ed published in Le Monde at the beginning of 2020 is just the latest in a long series (see here, here, here, here, or there). Will it have as much impact as the mass resignation of prominent ANR figures in 2016, who, refusing to cope with continuous budget cuts under Sarkozy and Hollande, perhaps helped increase the overall budget dedicated to the structure?
It‚Äôs uncertain, especially considering how the current executive treats demands coming ‚Äúfrom below‚Äù and considering that the likely candidate for the presidency of the HCERES is none other than Thierry Coulhon, a former advisor to the Fillon government and now advising Emmanuel Macron on ‚Äúeducation, higher education, research, and innovation‚Äù.
However, the unprecedented interest of this op-ed paradoxically lies in reminding us of a very simple but often forgotten fact: in terms of research evaluation, ‚Äúthe bottom‚Äù is actually ‚Äúthe top‚Äù since no one is better placed to assess scientific output than the researchers themselves. They are the ones, not ministers or the President, who are best positioned to anticipate upcoming revolutions, determine which research lines are dead ends and which are promising, or to evaluate the material and human resources required to achieve set goals.
With this idea in mind, members of the rogueESR collective urge the entire scientific community to engage with the question in their latest letter:

The second phase of this nascent movement of reaffirming the scholarly world as forming a community capable of setting its own rules, this immense freedom being balanced by a principle of responsibility towards society, requires everyone‚Äôs participation. What strategy can we employ, by curbing all forms of bureaucracy, to agree, beyond partisan divisions, on the University and the research system we aspire to bring to life. Our email is open to all thoughtful tactical and strategic proposals.

I seize the opportunity to submit a proposal as radically different from the current system as from the previous one. Given the ANR‚Äôs programmed failure, it might be tempting to nostalgically contemplate the past and its ‚Äúinter-ministerial funding‚Äù‚Äîless time-consuming and more flexible for researchers‚Äîbut this would be a serious mistake, in my opinion.
Indeed, if one can consider that the reforms which gave birth to the ANR were an opportunity for the then-government to hold a ‚Äúmodernization discourse‚Äù that masked‚Äîlike a smokescreen‚Äîthe upcoming budget cuts, these reforms were still based on strong dissatisfaction with the old system. It is informative to revisit the report on research studied at the National Assembly on December 21, 2004. Many criticisms targeted the overly hierarchical allocation of credits (following a ministry - institute - laboratory - researcher scheme) whose major flaw was to fuel local nepotisms, often allowing laboratory directors to distribute resources at their discretion; and often at the expense of the most innovative or risky projects carried by younger researchers still poorly integrated into the complex power games that academia has always known. The shift to project-based funding has at least had the virtue of de-siloing all researchers and establishing a horizontal competition theoretically allowing each to compete directly for resources.


A Framework-Breaking Proposal
Is it possible to combine the flexibility of the old system with the horizontality of the new, while taking a real step towards a more free, more creative science whose management would involve ‚Äúeveryone‚Äôs participation‚Äù? It seems to me that yes.
The idea is as follows: instead of awarding funding by project or by laboratory, the state could directly allocate a portion of its credits to each actor in the research process, according to a system blending scientific merit and seniority. From the PhD student at the end of their thesis to the senior research director, including the research engineer and the postdoc, each person contributing to advancing knowledge would thus control a fraction of the credits available for their branch.
At each hierarchical level, the allocation would increase significantly, reflecting despite everything the evolution of scientific expertise. In the field of cognitive neuroscience, for example, the state could allocate five thousand euros per year for doctoral students at the end of their thesis, twenty thousand euros for non-tenured researchers (i.e., postdocs), and fifty thousand euros for tenured researchers and research engineers. If this idea may seem subversive with respect to the traditional hierarchical organization, it is not by accident. In reality, it‚Äôs simply about pushing the logic of rogueESR to the limit.
If researchers are to collectively evaluate and control research, isn‚Äôt it natural to assign to each of them a part of the available resources, to be employed according to their expertise and motivations? Since it is common to consider that a PhD student at the end of their thesis has already become an expert regarding their research theme, and since postdocs are often seen as true locomotives of academia, isn‚Äôt it sensible to include these two categories in the collective system of evaluation and control being discussed?
A natural objection is that this organization seems at first glance highly individualistic, each researcher then having their little patch of land to cultivate their particular interests. However, it should be noted that the project-based funding as we know it is already highly individualistic since the funding is associated with a single person rather than a collective, both at the French and European levels. Moreover, in this new system, no one would have the ‚Äúfirepower‚Äù necessary to carry out major projects, so that collaboration and pooling of resources would be imposed on anyone with big scientific ambitions.
By setting up a platform allowing both the submission of projects, the call for contributions, and the allocation of resources, each actor could then organize a fundraising campaign among their peers, in exchange for an authorship place and/or a proportionate right to oversee the publications resulting from this pooling. The state could promote this type of cooperative logic by awarding additional funding to projects that have received enough contributions, thus breaking with the zero-sum game principle.


Fighting Academic ‚ÄúBranding‚Äù and the Reign of Researcher-Communicators
The great virtue of this system would be to put each researcher before the following dilemma: work alone with limited means or work collectively with significantly greater means, so that personal ambitions would systematically be weighed against scientific ambitions; and this, unlike the current system where building a personal reputation and brand (‚Äúacademic branding‚Äù) very largely conditions the ability to fulfill our scientific ambitions, benefiting the researchers most skilled in communication.
Such an initiative would undoubtedly multiply the inventiveness of researchers at every level and would also allow for better exploitation of the inter-individual differences that exist in academia. For example, in the field of neuroscience, as in many others, ‚Äútheorists‚Äù generally do not need a lot of their own resources to do their work. A few good computers suffice. However, they urgently need to be able to rely on work informing and constraining the theories they develop. In such a system, these same theorists could thus make their credits available to ‚Äúexperimentalists‚Äù who have submitted the most useful projects to them, or directly issue a call for contributions for the experiments they most need.



Proposed distribution schema


Certainly, such a reform could not be imposed on the scientific community overnight, and it would undoubtedly take years of local experimentation to develop the necessary tools and refine the logistical and ethical aspects of this entirely ‚Äúbottom-up‚Äù participative system, to borrow an Anglicism that scientists are fond of.
But if we want to hold all researchers accountable for the future of research, and if we want them all to intervene in its evaluation, if we want to fight both bureaucratic arbitrariness and hierarchical arbitrariness, we will have to give them the counterpart of this new responsibility: control over the available resources. Without this, a system proceeding by the nomination of representatives in charge of control, evaluation, and distribution of resources seems inevitable, whether they be laboratory directors or bureaucrats employed by central institutions like the ANR.
For dispensing with such representatives and for freeing the vital forces of academia while advocating self-management, it is essential that everyone contribute to this work of evaluation, orientation, and pooling.


To Go Further
As part of this collective movement, two public sessions of the ‚ÄúScience Policies‚Äù seminar will be held at the EHESS on January 30 and February 6 next. These meetings will undoubtedly provide an opportunity to discuss many other proposals imagined by researchers to reform the system as we know it.
See the program, here.

Exemple I.2 Parlant du fait que le cerveau ¬´aime se voir confirmer ses croyances¬ª, Idriss Aberkane ajoute que lorsque le cerveau ¬´projette une id√©e sur le monde et qu‚Äôelle est adoub√©e, il se cr√©e en lui une puissante vague de r√©compense dopaminergique¬ª. Ces trois points illustrent trois types d‚Äôerreurs pr√©sents dans le livre, erreurs √©videntes qu‚Äôun bon vulgarisateur n‚Äôaurait pas commises. La premi√®re consiste √† donner une information factuellement fausse qui interpelle imm√©diatement toute personne connaissant un tant soit peu la physiologie du syst√®me visuel. La seconde consiste √† extrapoler de fa√ßon fantaisiste la fonction du syst√®me dopaminergique, ignorant un fait contraire √©tabli depuis deux d√©cennies et central dans le travail d‚Äôinnombrables chercheurs. La troisi√®me consiste √† cr√©er de faux espoirs chez les individus qui esp√®rent des neurosciences de nouvelles avanc√©es th√©rapeutiques, en rapportant une hypoth√®se tr√®s discutable comme un fait av√©r√©.


II/ Erreurs d‚Äôappr√©ciation
Evidemment, toutes les donn√©es discut√©es ne sont pas fausses, mais le livre sombre souvent dans des erreurs d‚Äôappr√©ciation importantes.
Exemple II.1 L‚Äôune d‚Äôelle consiste √† laisser entendre au lecteur qu‚Äôil existerait dans le cerveau une entit√© qui commande, appel√©e aussi homoncule. Ce sophisme apparait en plusieurs endroits de son livre, comme lorsqu‚Äôil √©crit ¬´notre cerveau cherche √† faire taire les r√©seaux qui n‚Äôont pas la bonne r√©ponse et √† amplifier ceux qui l‚Äôont¬ª, ou lorsqu‚Äôil √©crit : ¬´L‚Äô√¢me humaine est un chariot tir√© par deux chevaux, l‚Äôun repr√©sentant nos passions (notre ¬´moi-qui-commande¬ª) et l‚Äôautre notre mod√©ration (notre ¬´moi v√©ritable¬ª)¬ª. Ces propos sont probl√©matiques √† l‚Äôheure o√π les neuroscientifiques essaient justement de faire comprendre au grand public que le cerveau est un organe dont les activit√©s s‚Äôauto-structurent et que les d√©cisions que nous prenons √©mergent de l‚Äôensemble de ces activit√©s plut√¥t que du jugement d‚Äôun d√©cideur interne.



Repr√©sentation de ¬´l‚Äôhomoncule¬ª: en pr√©sumant qu‚Äôil existe un ‚Äôd√©cideur interne‚Äô au cerveau, on est amen√© √† se demander comment d√©cide ce ‚Äôd√©cideur‚Äô, ce qui am√®ne √† pr√©sumer l‚Äôexistence d‚Äôun autre ‚Äôd√©cideur interne‚Äô, et ainsi de suite‚Ä¶ Le probl√®me se pose aussi bien pour la d√©cision que pour la perception.


Exemple II.2 La description que donne Idriss Aberkane de la stimulation √©lectrique transcranienne (tDCS en anglais) est encore plus sid√©rante, puisqu‚Äôil lui attribue le pouvoir d‚Äôinhiber dynamiquement les r√©seaux neuronaux qui ont ¬´tort¬ª et d‚Äôamplifier les r√©seaux qui ont ¬´raison¬ª, et ainsi de ¬´provoquer le g√©nie¬ª. Outre que le concept de r√©seau neuronal ayant ¬´tort¬ª ou ¬´raison¬ª est fort peu scientifique, l‚Äôauteur semble ignorer que, pour des raisons physiques, la pr√©cision spatio-temporelle de la tDCS est fondamentalement limit√©e : soit on inhibe, soit on active, et le r√©sultat a de toute mani√®re une influence sur des portions tr√®s larges de cortex, jamais sur des populations pr√©cises de neurones !
Pour rester sur la stimulation √©lectrique transcranienne, on rel√®vera que le livre est autocontradictoire lorsqu‚Äôil s‚Äôagit de discuter des neurotechnologies. Dans les premiers chapitres du livre, l‚Äôauteur passe son temps √† nous faire r√™ver avec les calculateurs prodiges et sugg√®re que l‚Äôutilisation des neurotechnologies permettra de faire de nous des g√©nies, sans jamais mettre en garde contre les m√©susages possibles de celles-ci. Pourtant, plusieurs chapitres plus loin, il √©crit ¬´le garagiste sait qu‚Äôil ne faut pas customiser un m√©canisme qu‚Äôon ne sait pas refaire. Ceux qui pr√©tendent augmenter le cerveau √† l‚Äôaide d‚Äôimplants non m√©dicaux semblent ignorer ce principe¬ª. On ne sait donc pas √† quoi s‚Äôen tenir. A-t-il chang√© d‚Äôavis sur la tDCS √† la lecture d‚Äôun billet de blog publi√© d√©but 2016 et d√©non√ßant les risques associ√©s √† son utilisation le grand public?


III/ Contradiction internes
Sentant peut-√™tre le vent tourner, Idriss Aberkane a apparemment √©crit son livre tr√®s rapidement, sur l‚Äôann√©e scolaire 2015-2016, en recyclant les travaux b√©n√©voles de blogueurs scientifiques et en les compilant dans ce qui restera sans doute comme son unique best-seller. D‚Äôailleurs, il √©crit lui-m√™me ¬´j‚Äôai pris l‚Äôhabitude de suivre un cours dans la perspective de devoir le donner moi-m√™me quelques jours, voire quelques heures apr√®s¬ª. Caract√©ristique du personnage, cet empressement et cette inaptitude √† s‚Äôassurer qu‚Äôil ma√Ætrise r√©ellement le savoir qu‚Äôil diffuse am√®nent Idriss Aberkane √† se contredire √† de nombreux autres endroits du livre. J‚Äôen donne deux exemples suppl√©mentaires ci-dessous.
Exemple III.1 Idriss Aberkane √©crit qu‚Äô¬´√† t√¢che √©gale, le cerveau de l‚Äôamateur consomme plus d‚Äô√©nergie que le cerveau de l‚Äôexpert¬ª. Pourtant dans sa description du calculateur prodige Gramm, il assure aussi qu‚Äôune mesure de la consommation c√©r√©brale de glucose a permis de montrer que ¬´si Gamm utilisait bien des aires communes √† lui et aux calculateurs ¬´normaux¬ª, il en utilisait aussi d‚Äôautres¬ª‚Ä¶ De la m√™me mani√®re, √† t√¢che √©gale, des activations c√©r√©brales plus importantes ont r√©cemment √©t√© observ√©es chez des experts musiciens par rapport √† des non-musiciens lors de la perception d‚Äôune partition de musique.
Exemple III.2 Au cours d‚Äôune t√©m√©raire tentative de description globale du cerveau √† partir d‚Äôune analogie avec le monde √©conomique, Idriss Aberkane propose que ¬´chaque aire [c√©r√©brale] est exportatrice et/ou importatrice d‚Äôun service¬ª et distingue ¬´produit neuronal de base¬ª et ¬´produit neuronal fini¬ª. Il ajoute alors que ¬´nous ne pouvons pas modifier les industries de base de notre cerveau, qui sont fix√©es par l‚Äô√©volution¬ª. Or, non seulement cette affirmation est rigoureusement fausse, mais l‚Äôauteur la contredit imm√©diatement apr√®s en voulant l‚Äôillustrer ! En effet, prenant √† t√©moin ¬´les neurones sensibles aux nombres du sillon intrapari√©tal¬ª, il donne un exemple d‚Äôaire c√©r√©brale pouvant parfaitement traiter une information purement culturelle et donc insignifiante √† l‚Äô√©chelle de l‚Äô√©volution (i.e, le nombre, qui doit √™tre diff√©renci√© de la quantit√© qu‚Äôil repr√©sente). Plus loin dans l‚Äôouvrage, il mentionne d‚Äôailleurs la formidable plasticit√© du cerveau, qui permet notamment aux aveugles d‚Äôutiliser leur cortex visuel pour mieux entendre. Cette modification des fonctions de base de nos aires c√©r√©brales au cours de l‚Äôapprentissage et du d√©veloppement correspond √† l‚Äôhypoth√®se du ¬´recyclage neuronal¬ª propos√©e notamment par Stanislas Dehaene.

IV/ Une vision du r√¥le social des neurosciences qui pose question
Tout au long de ses 288 pages le livre tente de d√©montrer l‚Äôimportance des neurosciences pour la soci√©t√©. Si on sent beaucoup de bonne volont√© et d‚Äôenthousiasme, certaines de ses r√©flexions donnent aussi le tournis. J‚Äôen recense quelques-unes ci-dessous, sans souci de coh√©rence car le livre en est lui-m√™me largement d√©pourvu, comme nous venons de le voir.
Exemple IV.1 Voulant illustrer l‚Äôutilit√© des neurosciences pour la vie sentimentale, Idriss Aberkane √©crit: ¬´Les ressorts neuroergonomiques de l‚Äôattraction, de l‚Äôaddiction et de la formation m√©canique des couples demeurent [‚Ä¶] tr√®s int√©ressants pour qui veut am√©liorer son exp√©rience romantique d‚Äôautrui (sic)¬ª. √âtonnamment, il encha√Æne alors avec une description des techniques de manipulation employ√©es par les ¬´pick-up artists¬ª (dragueurs de rue) et dont le principe central serait de susciter ¬´une d√©pendance forte de la cible, en lui offrant, en quantit√©s contr√¥l√©es, les √©motions, mots et comportements qu‚Äôelle d√©sire, souvent sans le savoir¬ª. S‚Äôensuit une longue discussion des diff√©rences hommes-femmes dans le rapport √† la sexualit√© o√π l‚Äôon apprend par exemple que les stripteaseuses ont tendance ¬´√† recevoir des pourboires significativement plus √©lev√©s durant la p√©riode pr√©c√©dant leur ovulation¬ª. Les mouvements f√©ministes appr√©cieront la subtile neuroergonomicit√© de ces analyses.
Exemple IV.2 Discutant des enjeux entre consommation et neurosciences, l‚Äôauteur en vient √† parler de la neuro√©conomie, sous-discipline qui s‚Äôint√©resse √† la prise de d√©cision. Pour lui, ¬´nous n‚Äôavons fait qu‚Äôeffleurer le potentiel immense de cette ¬´neurovaleur¬ª payable en argent r√©el¬ª et il sugg√®re que les neuro√©conomistes devraient d√©velopper ¬´des m√©thodes permettant d‚Äôamplifier neuronalement la valeur d‚Äôun bien ou d‚Äôun service, augmentant par l√† m√™me son prix¬ª. Si ces recommandations permettent de comprendre pourquoi les entreprises du CAC40 s‚Äôint√©ressent √† lui, on se demande ce qu‚Äôelles viennent faire dans un bouquin cens√© lib√©rer notre cerveau. En effet, jusqu‚Äôici, les chercheurs concern√©s par la libert√© c√©r√©brale avaient tendance √† lutter contre les techniques de neuromarketing et l‚Äôinvasion de la publicit√© dans l‚Äôespace public plut√¥t qu‚Äô√† vouloir les rendre plus puissantes‚Ä¶
Bien souvent, Idriss Aberkane s‚Äôesbaudit devant la r√©ussite d‚ÄôApple et de Steve Jobs qui, selon lui, ¬´vend essentiellement de la connaissance¬ª, alors m√™me qu‚ÄôApple est une des entreprises les plus ferm√©e en la mati√®re (algorithmes non partag√©s, syst√®mes d‚Äôexploitation opaques, etc.) et que son fonds de commerce repose surtout sur la vente de smartphones‚Ä¶ Il r√©p√®te ainsi son admiration pour le mod√®le am√©ricain et pour la Silicon Valley, au d√©triment du mod√®le fran√ßais et de l‚Äôuniversit√© Paris-Saclay qui semble avoir √©t√© particuli√®rement traumatique pour lui.
Malgr√© tout, en d‚Äôautres endroits du livre, il met en garde contre ce qu‚Äôil appelle le ¬´neurofascisme¬ª et qui consisterait en une confiscation des technologies de l‚Äôinformation et des neurotechnologies par les gouvernements et les entreprises, au d√©triment des citoyens. Or, comme il le reconna√Æt lui-m√™me, les Etats-Unis sont les champions de l‚Äôespionnage des populations et du d√©tournement des neurosciences √† des fins militaires ou de torture‚Ä¶
On ne comprend donc pas bien, mais peu importe car il y existe une solution : ¬´la seule chose qui puisse pr√©server du neurofascisme, c‚Äôest une majorit√© consciente de sa neuroergonomie, c‚Äôest-√†-dire de l‚Äôempreinte de ses neurones au travail. Si c‚Äôest le cas, l‚Äôhumanit√© est saine et sauve¬ª.
Apr√®s Idriss hyperdocteur, Idriss grandiose sauveur de l‚Äôhumanit√©?


Conclusion
Ayant d√©j√† pass√© une bonne partie de mon week-end sur le cas Idriss Aberkane, je vais m‚Äôarr√™ter-l√†, en esp√©rant en avoir dit suffisamment pour remettre les pendules √† l‚Äôheure. Si je me suis lanc√© dans cette entreprise chronophage de d√©construction, c‚Äôest sans doute parce que les deux lignes de son CV qui font de lui un ¬´sp√©cialiste des neurosciences¬ª se retrouvent √©galement sur le mien. Comme lui, j‚Äôaspire √† d√©mocratiser les fruits de la recherche en neurosciences, mais contrairement √† lui, j‚Äôaimerais le faire sans discr√©diter ma communaut√© et sans induire en erreur le grand public √† la faveur d‚Äôune ambition personnelle.
Partant du parall√®le entre son cursus et le mien, certains ont sugg√©r√© que ma critique d‚ÄôIdriss Aberkane d√©rivait d‚Äôun irr√©pressible sentiment de jalousie face √† sa r√©ussite et √† son exposition. A ceux-l√†, je r√©ponds deux choses. Premi√®rement, n‚Äô√©tant pas chercheur et ne publiant pas d‚Äôarticles scientifiques, sa r√©ussite se d√©finit en dehors du monde acad√©mique tandis que la mienne se d√©finit en dedans. Cela signifie que si j‚Äôemployais les m√™mes m√©thodes pour obtenir une exposition m√©diatique (que je ne cherche pas au-del√† du lectorat de ce blog), ma carri√®re serait vite compromise. Deuxi√®mement, ses choix semblent avant tout guid√©s par une terrible impatience de r√©ussir : CV bidonn√©, diffusion d‚Äôun savoir superficiel et parfois faux, expertise de pacotille dans les domaines √† la mode ; tous les ingr√©dients me paraissent r√©unis pour un succ√®s √©ph√©m√®re suivi de lendemains qui d√©chantent.

En effet, si l‚Äôon peut consid√©rer que les r√©formes qui ont fait na√Ætre l‚ÄôANR furent l‚Äôoccasion pour le gouvernement alors en place de tenir un ‚Äúdiscours de modernisation‚Äù cachant ‚Äî tel un √©cran de fum√©e ‚Äî les coupes budg√©taires √† venir, ces r√©formes s‚Äôappuyaient tout de m√™me sur un vif m√©contentement √† l‚Äô√©gard de l‚Äôancien syst√®me. Il est √† ce titre instructif de relire le rapport sur la recherche √©tudi√© √† l‚ÄôAssembl√©e Nationale le 21 d√©cembre 2004. De nombreuses critiques visaient alors l‚Äôallocation trop pyramidale des cr√©dits (suivant un sch√©ma minist√®re - institut - laboratoire - chercheur) et dont le grand d√©faut √©tait d‚Äôalimenter les n√©potismes locaux en laissant les directeurs de laboratoire libres de r√©partir les ressources selon leur gr√© ; et souvent au d√©triment des projets les plus innovants ou les plus risqu√©s port√©s par des chercheurs plus jeunes et encore mal ins√©r√©s dans les jeux de pouvoirs complexes que le monde acad√©mique a toujours connu. Le passage √† un financement par projet a au moins eu cette vertu de d√©senclaver tous les chercheurs et d‚Äôinstaurer une comp√©tition horizontale permettant en th√©orie √† chacun de concourir directement pour l‚Äôobtention des ressources.


Une proposition hors-cadre
Est-il possible de combiner la flexibilit√© de l‚Äôancien syst√®me avec l‚Äôhorizontalit√© du nouveau, tout en faisant un vrai pas vers une science plus libre, plus cr√©ative et dont la gestion impliquerait la ‚Äúparticipation de tous‚Äù? Il me semble que oui.
L‚Äôid√©e est la suivante: au lieu d‚Äôattribuer les financements par projet ou par laboratoire, l‚Äô√âtat pourrait directement attribuer une partie de ses cr√©dits √† chaque acteur de la recherche, selon un syst√®me m√™lant m√©rite scientifique et anciennet√©. De l‚Äô√©tudiant en fin de th√®se jusqu‚Äôau directeur de recherche hors-classe, en passant par l‚Äôing√©nieur d‚Äô√©tude et le post-doctorant, chaque personne contribuant √† faire avancer le savoir contr√¥lerait ainsi une fraction des cr√©dits disponibles pour sa branche.
A chaque √©chelon hi√©rarchique, la dotation augmenterait sensiblement, de mani√®re √† refl√©ter malgr√© tout l‚Äô√©volution de l‚Äôexpertise scientifique. Dans le domaine des neurosciences cognitives par exemple, l‚Äô√âtat pourrait attribuer cinq mille euros par an pour les doctorants en fin de th√®se, vingt mille euros pour les chercheurs non-titulaires (i.e les post-docs), et cinquante mille euros pour les chercheurs et ing√©nieurs de recherche titulaires. Si cette id√©e peut para√Ætre subversive vis-√†-vis de l‚Äôorganisation hi√©rarchique classique, ce n‚Äôest pas un hasard. En r√©alit√©, il s‚Äôagit simplement de pousser la logique de rogueESR jusqu‚Äôau bout.
Si les chercheurs sont amen√©s √† √©valuer et √† contr√¥ler collectivement la recherche, n‚Äôest-il pas naturel d‚Äôassigner √† chacun d‚Äôentre eux une partie des ressources disponibles, √† employer selon leurs expertises et leurs motivations? Puisqu‚Äôil est commun de consid√©rer qu‚Äôun √©tudiant en fin de th√®se est d√©j√† devenu expert vis-√†-vis de son th√®me de recherche, et qu‚Äôil est fr√©quent d‚Äôobserver des post-doctorants se comporter en v√©ritables locomotives acad√©miques, n‚Äôest-il pas sens√© d‚Äôinclure ces deux cat√©gories dans le syst√®me d‚Äô√©valuation et de contr√¥le collectif dont il est question?
Une objection naturelle est que cette organisation semble √† premi√®re vue hautement individualiste, chaque chercheur disposant alors de son petit lopin de terre pour cultiver ses int√©r√™ts particuliers. Cependant, il faut remarquer que le financement par projet tel que nous le connaissons est d√©j√† hautement individualiste puisque les financements sont associ√©s √† une seule personne plut√¥t qu‚Äô√† un collectif, aussi bien √† l‚Äô√©chelle fran√ßaise qu‚Äô√† l‚Äô√©chelle europ√©enne. De plus, dans ce nouveau syst√®me, personne n‚Äôaurait la ‚Äúforce de frappe‚Äù n√©cessaire pour mener √† bien de grands projets, de sorte que la collaboration et la mise en commun des ressources s‚Äôimposera √† quiconque ayant de grandes ambitions scientifiques.
En mettant en place une plate-forme permettant √† la fois le d√©p√¥t de projets, l‚Äôappel √† contributions et l‚Äôattribution des ressources, chaque acteur pourrait alors organiser une lev√©e de fond aupr√®s de ses pairs, moyennant une place d‚Äôauteur et/ou un droit de regard proportionnel sur les publications r√©sultant de cette mise en commun. L‚Äô√âtat pourrait favoriser ce type de logique coop√©rative en attribuant des financements suppl√©mentaires aux projets ayant re√ßus suffisamment de contributions, rompant ainsi avec le principe du jeu √† somme nulle.


La lutte contre le ¬´branding¬ª acad√©mique et le r√®gne des chercheurs-communicants
La grande vertu de ce syst√®me serait de mettre chaque chercheur face au dilemme suivant: travailler seul avec des moyens limit√©s ou travailler collectivement avec des moyens bien plus importants, de sorte que les ambitions personnelles se trouveraient syst√©matiquement mises en balance avec les ambitions scientifiques ; et ce, contrairement au syst√®me actuel o√π la construction d‚Äôune r√©putation et d‚Äôune marque de fabrique personnelle (‚Äúacademic branding‚Äù) conditionne tr√®s largement la capacit√© √† assouvir nos ambitions scientifiques, au b√©n√©fice des chercheurs les plus dou√©s pour la communication.
Une telle initiative d√©multiplierait sans doute l‚Äôinventivit√© des chercheurs √† chaque √©chelon et permettrait √©galement de tirer un meilleur parti des diff√©rences inter-individuelles qui existent dans le monde acad√©mique. Par exemple, dans le domaine des neurosciences comme dans bien d‚Äôautres, les ¬´th√©oriciens¬ª n‚Äôont g√©n√©ralement pas besoin de beaucoup de ressources propres pour effectuer leur travail. Quelques bons ordinateurs suffisent. En revanche, ils ont cruellement besoin de pouvoir s‚Äôappuyer sur des travaux informant et contraignant les th√©ories qu‚Äôils √©laborent. Dans un tel syst√®me, ces m√™mes th√©oriciens pourraient ainsi mettre leurs cr√©dits √† disposition des ¬´exp√©rimentalistes¬ª ayant d√©pos√© les projets les plus utiles √† leur yeux, ou bien √©mettre directement un appel √† contribution pour les exp√©riences dont ils ont le plus besoin.



Sch√©ma de r√©partition propos√©


Certes, une telle r√©forme ne pourra pas √™tre impos√©e √† la communaut√© scientifique du jour au lendemain, et il faudrait sans doute des ann√©es d‚Äôexp√©rimentation locale pour d√©velopper les outils n√©cessaires et peaufiner les aspects logistiques et √©thiques de ce syst√®me participatif enti√®rement ‚Äúbottom-up‚Äù, pour reprendre un anglicisme dont les scientifiques sont friands.
Mais si l‚Äôon veut responsabiliser tous les chercheurs vis-√†-vis de l‚Äôavenir de la recherche, et si l‚Äôon veut que tous interviennent dans l‚Äô√©valuation de cette derni√®re, si l‚Äôon veut lutter √† la fois contre l‚Äôarbitraire bureaucratique et l‚Äôarbitraire hi√©rarchique, il faudra bien leur donner la contrepartie de cette responsabilit√© nouvelle: le contr√¥le sur les ressources disponibles. Sans cela, un syst√®me proc√©dant par nomination de repr√©sentants d√©positaires du contr√¥le, de l‚Äô√©valuation et de la r√©partition des ressources para√Æt in√©vitable, qu‚Äôil s‚Äôagisse de directeurs de laboratoire ou de bureaucrates employ√©s par des institutions centrales comme l‚ÄôANR.
Pour se passer de tels repr√©sentants et pour lib√©rer les forces vives du monde acad√©mique tout en pr√¥nant l‚Äôautogestion, il est essentiel que chacun contribue √† ce travail d‚Äô√©valuation, d‚Äôorientation et de mise en commun.


Pour aller plus loin
Dans le cadre de ce mouvement collectif, deux s√©ances publiques du s√©minaires ‚ÄúPolitiques des Sciences‚Äù‚Äô se tiendront √† l‚ÄôEHESS le 30 janvier et le 6 f√©vrier prochain. Ces rencontres seront sans aucun doute l‚Äôoccasion de discuter de nombreuses autres propositions imagin√©es par les chercheurs pour refonder le syst√®me tel que nous le connaissons.

title: Brain Weather: How Our Emotions Fluctuate with the Seasons
text:
For most of us, despite the political frustrations that afflict some, summer is synonymous with good mood. This trend directly affects web platforms like Twitter, where positively connoted words become more frequent (Golder & Maci, 2011) while negatively connoted words decrease. The analysis of mood changes on the web (‚Äúsentiment analysis‚Äù in English) suggests that even our anxieties ease as Wikipedia searches related to various illnesses drop during the summer period.
What happens in our brain that might explain why our vocabulary and moods warm up as our skins caramelize? To answer this question, we must delve into a scientific field as vast as it is fascinating: chronobiology, which, as its etymology indicates, studies how organisms adapt to the temporal cycles of Mother Nature.



The analysis of internet users‚Äô behavior on Twitter and Wikipedia illustrates mood changes throughout the year. For example, searches related to various psychiatric disorders increase in winter and early spring, just as tweets containing keywords like ‚Äúanger,‚Äù ‚Äúsadness,‚Äù or ‚Äúanxiety‚Äù rise in autumn (Dzogang et al., 2016, see also).


While the structure of the human brain is remarkably stable compared to that of smaller mammals (like the squirrel, whose brain shrinks by 10 to 25% in winter!), most of our body systems still adapt, to varying degrees, to the differences in light, humidity, and temperature that characterize each season.
But in terms of the ‚Äúseasonality of emotions,‚Äù it is primarily the famous serotonin that we should look at. Involved in mood regulation, learning, appetite, and impulsivity, a series of studies demonstrates the existence of a ‚Äúcircannual‚Äù rhythm in this complex neuromodulator which is also one of the most important therapeutic targets for contemporary psychiatry.

Serotonin and Sunshine
Thus, the membrane transporter of serotonin, which helps clear the molecule after it has been released, decreases in concentration in summer and increases in winter (Praschak-Rieder et al., 2008; Kalbitzer et al., 2010). This annual variation is especially relevant as it appears absent in those who suffer from seasonal depression (seasonal affective disorder in English; McMahon et al., 2016). It is striking to note that classical antidepressants mimic the effect of the sun, as they also act by reducing the effectiveness of the serotonin transporter.
Two other aspects of the system also fluctuate throughout the year: the activity of the serotonergic neurons themselves increases with day length (Green et al., 2015) as does the density of certain receptors that bridge the ‚Äúserotonin signal‚Äù and our behavior (the 5HT1A, for purists). Not to mention the cycles observed in the synthesis and degradation pathways of the molecule (Maes et al., 1995; Lambert et al., 2002; Luykx et al., 2013)‚Ä¶ More signal at the base, less evacuation, and more receptors to receive it, all point in the same direction, making it quite natural to think that the serotonergic system as a whole significantly contributes to the fluctuation of our moods, and perhaps even some of our cognitive abilities (Keller et al., 2005; Meyer et al., 2016)!



On the left, representation of the transporter responsible for serotonin reuptake after its release (excerpt from a detailed and interesting blog post on the sometimes exaggerated role of the serotonin transporter in popularizing psychiatric disorders). On the right, fluctuation of the transporter‚Äôs expression throughout the year, with its characteristic peak in mid-winter (Kalbitzer et al., 2010).


Should we then soak up the sun in summer to charge up on good mood for the entire year? Is the phenomenon related to excessive sunbathing or the intensive use of tanning beds observed in some? It‚Äôs hard to say, especially since we don‚Äôt yet know if light has a direct impact or if the observed effects are due to another factor, which could be related to dietary changes or increased physical activity in summer.
It would therefore be reductive and even rash to hope to explain everything by serotonin, especially since other related chemical signals (like dopamine) also vary with the seasons. Regarding exposure to solar or artificial UV, a recent study conducted on mice suggests that it is actually endorphins that explain the development of true addictive behaviors (Fell et al., 2014). The idea is quite simple: prolonged exposure to UV causes a series of micro-traumas to our skin, which reacts by releasing these natural painkillers known as endorphins. In turn, these endorphins induce a feeling of relaxation and well-being similar to what joggers feel after a long run. And like athletes, a small proportion of individuals sensitive to this mechanism would develop a form of UV addiction that is increasingly concerning in the United States.


A Summer Picture Not So Rosy
Furthermore, as often in science, what seems obvious at first glance turns out to be more complex than it appears. For example, contrary to a deeply rooted popular belief, it is not during winter that the deepest psychological distresses manifest. The vast majority of available data indicates that suicide rates actually peak at the end of spring and early summer.
Conducted in the United States and Mexico, a study published on July 28 in the journal Nature Climate Change even shows a clear correlation between suicide rates and temperature variations from one year to the next. In other words, for a given month, suicide rates increase when temperatures are above usual values. And the effect sizes are so impressive that researchers estimate that global warming could have an impact similar to that of an economic crisis by 2050: for each additional degree, the suicide rate increases by 0.7% in the US and 2.1% in Mexico. To better understand the link between these two variables, researchers then analyzed 600 million tweets posted in these two regions. Unexpectedly but consistently with epidemiological observations, this second analysis reveals a positive correlation between monthly temperature and the number of ‚Äúdepressive connotation tweets.‚Äù



Map showing the effect of temperatures higher (in red) or lower (in blue) than seasonal normals on suicide rates in the United States and Mexico (excerpt from Burke et al., 2018).


So, while summer brings its share of joys (and serotonin?) to most of us, it also represents a difficult period for vulnerable and fragile people. If the authors of the American study support the idea that the increase in suicide rates rests on a biological mechanism, they do not specify which one. In any case, it is known that summer can exacerbate social isolation, especially among those who do not have the chance to go on vacation and among the elderly (about 40% of the population in France).
Hence the usefulness of postcards!

title: A Remarkable Brain Factory
text:
‚ÄúThe future of our country must necessarily be a future of scientists, thinkers, because that is precisely what we are sowing; we are sowing opportunities for intelligence,‚Äù proclaimed Fidel Castro on January 15, 1960. In 1959, the country had three universities, compared to more than sixty today. The literacy rate jumped from around 70% to over 99% in 2012 (the latest available figures). That of the neighboring island, Haiti, stagnates at 62%1.
1¬†On the occasion of the 20th anniversary of the Cuban Speleological Society, Academy of Sciences. http://en.granma.cu/special-in-honor-of-fidel-s-90th-birthday/2016-08-12/a-talent-for-doing-the-impossible2¬†According to the United Nations Development Programme.3¬†For example, from 2007-2012, Cuba invested 11.9% of its GDP in education, a world record.Today, Havana exports doctors and researchers worldwide (see Hernando Calvo Ospina‚Äôs article on page 52). Cuba‚Äôs successes in the biomedical field are largely due to state efforts in public education (which represent more than 10% of the gross domestic product2). The country is now on par with the United States in terms of life expectancy (78.5 years) and infant mortality (5 per 1,000)3. Thus, doctors constitute a true economic boon for the island (the primary source of foreign exchange, ahead of remittances and tourism).
Thanks to a 2000 agreement with Hugo Ch√°vez‚Äôs Venezuela, the island long received up to one hundred thousand barrels of oil per day (at subsidized prices) in exchange for which more than ten thousand Cuban doctors and academics work on Venezuelan soil4.
4¬†Statistics from the World Health Organization, 2016.


Tom√°s Munita. ‚Äî Street scene in downtown Havana, 2016


Director of the Cuban Neuroscience Center (CNEURO) in Havana, Dr.¬†Mitchell Vald√©s-Sosa, 67, has been a privileged witness to the history of Cuban science development. Exiled to Chicago under the dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista (1952-1959), his father returned to the island in 1961 to practice obstetrics and address the exodus of the medical bourgeoisie fleeing the revolution5. He witnessed the creation of the Centro Nacional de Investigaciones Cient√≠ficas (CNIC, equivalent to the National Center for Scientific Research, CNRS) in 1965, the arrival of numerous researchers and doctors sent by the USSR of Leonid Brezhnev or Chile of Salvador Allende to train the first generation of local specialists, and the defense of the island‚Äôs first PhD in 1971. In the early 1980s, Cuban research moved away from the Soviet model, deemed too centralized, too bureaucratic, and too rigid. The government increasingly granted autonomy to researchers whom it consulted frequently.
5¬†It is estimated that Cuba lost more than a third of its doctors between 1959 and 1961.During the prosperous years preceding perestroika and the ‚Äúspecial period,‚Äù Vald√©s-Sosa and his brother Pedro contributed to some of the major achievements in local neuroscience, such as building the first Cuban computer-assisted brain imaging system and designing algorithms for processing neural signals still used today.
China, a privileged partner of the island, has just been authorized to open a pharmaceutical company on the territory
The budget for Cuban research remains limited. Thus, the government promotes short circuits in which fundamental research, applied research, and production chains are concentrated in one place. For instance, CNEURO brings together biologists, mathematicians, physicists, doctors involved in various clinical trials, and several specialized technicians. Vald√©s-Sosa proudly notes that CNEURO produces ‚Äúsome six thousand prostheses and hearing aids each year, allowing for early diagnosis of deafness in very young children.‚Äù
BioCubaFarma, the public company that encompasses all actors in the biomedical industry, holds over two thousand patents and exports several hundred different products to Brazil, Vietnam, South Africa, Venezuela, Algeria, and Iran. China, a privileged partner of Cuba, has just been authorized to open a pharmaceutical company on Cuban territory. Given the low cost and good training of health professionals in Cuba, Canadians are also interested, as are some French companies.
Cancer Vaccine Since the December 2014 agreements that led to the reopening of the US embassy in Havana and a thaw in relations between the United States and Cuba, two promising Cuban molecules have been undergoing clinical trials in the United States: a lung cancer vaccine and a drug for diabetic gangrene6. In return, administrative easing was supposed to allow American companies to export a broader range of products to Cuba, until Mr.¬†Donald Trump backtracked in Miami on June 16, 2017. While the academic world enthusiastically welcomed these agreements that lay the groundwork for scientific cooperation between the two countries, there is still a long way to go. Washington never forgets to remind that ‚ÄúCuba is a dictatorship,‚Äù and the Congress recently invoked the Cuba Democracy Act (1992) to impose a contractual clause enjoining Cuban pediatricians not to use American equipment they receive to torture their patients7‚Ä¶ This provoked the indignation of doctors and researchers.
6¬†Cohen et al., 2015. Advancing neuroscience interactions with Cuba. Proceedings of the National Academy of Science (link)7¬†See the article in Science, which mentions the previous difficulties associated with exporting biomedical equipment. http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2014/12/researchers-applaud-us-cuba-accord


Tom√°s Munita. ‚Äî Revolution Square, Havana, 2014


However, despite the altruistic vocation8 of the ‚Äúrevolutionary medicine‚Äù initially promoted by Ernesto ‚ÄúChe‚Äù Guevara, the Cuban scientific system is not without contradictions. Doctors are often sent abroad as part of a two-year civic service, during which they are housed in closely monitored camps and are required not to leave their assigned region under penalty of sanctions. Not to mention the measures devised by Washington to motivate would-be deserters9, whose remuneration is around 60 euros per month (they receive several hundred euros when on mission abroad).
8¬†Source: https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/31/515.5599¬†Like when Cuba sent more than 400 doctors to combat the Ebola epidemic on African soil.The government has launched a census program for twins to better predict the onset of certain diseases
In addition to uncertainties related to the Trump administration‚Äôs reluctance towards US-Cuban trade and tourism, the hopes following the opening of the biomedical sector are ‚Äúdarkened by financial difficulties,‚Äù explains Pascal Belin, research director at the Timone Neuroscience Institute (INT) in Marseille. Belin, who has been collaborating with his counterparts in Havana for over ten years, believes that Cuban laboratories are full of ‚Äútalented researchers who would make excellent additions to French institutions,‚Äù but their development depends, according to him, on the establishment of international partnerships, particularly focused on the exchange of skills and equipment. Not to mention more flexible emigration procedures on the Cuban side.
While the INT donated an electroencephalogram device to Dr.¬†Vald√©s-Sosa‚Äôs team, Belin notes that other countries are ahead of France in the field of cooperation with Cuba. Maastricht University (Netherlands), for example, offered an MRI scanner worth several million euros to CNEURO and created a joint doctoral program that benefits from Cuba‚Äôs expertise in so-called ‚Äúmultimodal‚Äù neuroimaging10.
10¬†Combination of several simultaneous brain activity measurements, such as electroencephalogram and MRITo better predict the onset and progression of neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer‚Äôs ‚Äî increasingly common due to the aging population ‚Äî the Cuban government launched in 2004 a vast program to census all the twins on the island. With almost all (95%) of them recorded, over a hundred thousand individuals can now be mobilized to study genetic heredity and gene-environment interactions in one of the most racially diverse countries. In the specific field of cognitive neuroscience, a long-term partnership with Cuba would offer the possibility of thoroughly examining the intercultural differences between European countries and one of the last communist societies, paving the way for a better understanding of the complex dynamics governing the relationship between social structures and individual behaviors.

title: Between 1 Euro and 1 Billion: Your Budget for Eternal Life
text:
Are you fed up with the human condition and tired of ear hair? Do you wonder why your deserving ego should dissolve into the great Nothing that is the great All?
This manual is for you. It outlines the main steps to keep alive the wild hope of eternal life. Against all odds, nature, and everything else!
However, eternal life has become a business that requires you to ask yourself a crucial question: how much to invest?
Any resemblance between this pyramid-shaped table of contents and any social hierarchy is purely coincidental.

title: Between 1 Euro and 1 Billion: Your Budget for Eternal Life
text:
With 1 euro‚Ä¶
With this symbolic euro, light a candle in front of the local patron saint and pray, because as Blaise Pascal says in his famous wager:
‚ÄúLet us weigh the gain and the loss in wagering that God is. Let us estimate these two chances: if you win, you win everything; if you lose, you lose nothing. Wager, then, without hesitation that He is.‚Äù (Pens√©es, 1670)
Incidentally, stop smoking, this should help you finance the next steps. If you do not wish to quit smoking, question your motivations: are you really a serious candidate for immortality?
Otherwise, stay calm and try to help others around you to be calm as well. In the absence of resources, they are your best survival asset: without a social group or in a troubled social group, you risk depression or anxiety [PDF], which tend to be poorly tolerated when they last too long‚Ä¶

title: Between 1 Euro and 1 Billion: Your Budget for Eternal Life
text:
Between 1 and 100 euros
Let‚Äôs be honest: this amount is a bit tight for immortality. As hope supposedly keeps us alive, start by putting 2 euros and a Euromillions ticket in a drawer.
Then invest in a good pair of shoes and start jogging. In reasonable doses, sport has great virtues for an organ that needs special care because, unlike the liver, heart, or lungs, it is not easily replaceable: the brain.



Immuno-stained hippocampal section - Harvard.edu/Brainbow


Even though it is estimated that it would take about 3,000 years for a human brain to lose half of its neurons, it would be a pity to live as long as Highlander if you have Alzheimer‚Äôs. Fortunately, physical exercise is a key factor in neurogenesis in the hippocampus, the brain structure that stores your memories.

title: Between 1 Euro and 1 Billion: Your Budget for Eternal Life
text:
Between 100 and 1,000 euros
Have you quit smoking and taken up sport? Among the other measures to take while waiting for the elixir of youth that will grant you eternal life, watch your diet. Not too much alcohol, soda, gluten, red meat, fish‚Ä¶ How about a little dandelion juice with your broccoli?
Stop! That would be too simple. As our national Elise Lucet has shown, water, fruits, vegetables, or milk from traditional agriculture still contain too many of those damned pesticides. You will often need a little more money to eat more organically. Annoying, yes, but the link between these chemicals and diseases like Parkinson‚Äôs is so clear that it is officially considered a professional disease among farmers. It even seems that the accumulation of pesticides due to too much milk consumption (more than 0.5L/day) may facilitate the emergence of associated symptoms.
Compared to other substances, the impact of pesticides is easily objectifiable because dopaminergic neurons ‚Äì which pesticides target ‚Äì are a rare and fragile resource. Largely grouped in a small nucleus in the middle of the brain, they represent roughly less than 0.5% of all your neurons, but they are involved in countless cognitive functions: learning, movement, decision-making, mood, motivation, attention, and concentration, to name a few.
Luckily, the nutritional problem is fairly simple for us French: partly linked to wine (red) consumption, rich in resveratrol, the ‚ÄúFrench paradox‚Äù allows our gastronomy to be quite advanced on longevity issues despite certain rule breaches. If you can afford it, the pleasure of eating well will easily surpass the desire to eat a lot.

title: Between 1 Euro and 1 Billion: Your Budget for Eternal Life
text:
Between 1,000 and 10,000 euros
Congratulations, with this amount, you can afford health insurance! More than 3 million French do not have this chance. It will replace your teeth, glasses, and other hearing aids in the centuries to come. Because even if gene therapy allowed your cells to regenerate indefinitely, even if you spent eternity in a sterile room eating pasteurized food, good old physical-chemical erosion would continue to wear out all the inert elements that make you up.
With the dismantling of public health services, your insurance may also have to pay for your potential cancer, whose occurrence will be more likely the longer you live. Indeed, cancer remains a highly random process that can never be completely curbed by eliminating external risk factors. It‚Äôs frustrating, but this risk will indeed approach 100% if you manage to extend your longevity by several centuries (compared to 50% for a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù life of 70 or 80 years). Ironically, immortality is a cardinal property of many cancerous lineages, the most famous being the HeLa strain.
Also, keep part of this budget for distractions and entertainment. Otherwise, your hypothetical immortality could become deadly boring. Start by buying a pair of Google Glass! In addition to supporting these apostles of ‚Äúdeath defeated‚Äù in their philanthropic endeavor, acquiring this technological gem that you do not (yet) need could help you overcome the small dangers of daily life. In other words, those that mere mortals can afford to neglect but could seriously jeopardize your immortality plans: automatic detection of potential terrorists in the street, real-time driving aid, lightning strike probability, etc.
Always remember, if the mere mortal can compensate with a life rich in emotions and meaning, the ‚Äúopportunity cost‚Äù associated with an avoidable death tends towards infinity for an aspirant to immortality, like the number of years that would have been so foolishly lost.

title: Between 1 Euro and 1 Billion: Your Budget for Eternal Life
text:
Between 10,000 and 100,000 euros
At this stage, you will start enjoying some services that most of your fellow citizens cannot afford. Before proceeding, please check if you have paid your taxes for those who cannot afford health insurance, because you wouldn‚Äôt want to live eternally with an irritating pack of ‚Äútoothless‚Äù people under your windows, would you?
Once this formality is done, first go to the Check-up Center of the American Hospital in Neuilly-sur-Seine. You will spend about 5,000 euros for an exhaustive health check that should help curb many lesions and diseases at their earliest stage. Cardiac ultrasound, lung scan, extensive blood tests, body fat percentage: immortality is a daily battle that requires you to learn to love hospitals and doctors!
Back home, open your web browser and visit the website of Illumina, the world leader in genetic sequencing for individuals. For about 1,000 euros, you will get a complete transcription of your genome on DVD. But as it would be utterly pointless to examine these 3 billion A, T, C, G letters under Microsoft Word, you will need the services of a greedy team of bioinformaticians and professional geneticists to ‚Äúdecode‚Äù your genetic identity (for example, at Cypher Genomics). If needed, their results could help you benefit more easily from targeted therapies ‚Äì that is, adapted to your genetic identity and its weaknesses.
In another vein, we also recommend investing in a heavy and possibly elevated car. In the long term, the automotive risk factor should not be overlooked, and no biotechnology has yet proven effective in road accidents (fourth leading cause of death). Well-filled wallets will be happy to learn that SUV and sedan drivers can reduce this risk by two or three times, as the weight of their car is an advantage in many types of collisions.
Welcome also, the armored bodywork that will help protect you from itinerant crime and civil wars that socioeconomic inequalities might favor in the coming decades.

title: Between 1 Euro and 1 Billion: Your Budget for Eternal Life
text:
Between 100,000 and 1,000,000 euros
Sorry, but the biomedical field has little more to offer you. Certainly, your substantial budget might eventually give you access to some emerging techniques like hadron therapy (extremely precise radiation therapy), replacement organs (available on the black market), as well as the most advanced bioprostheses ‚Äì like this artificial heart designed by Carmat. Hurrah for France. But this is where the fantasy of immortality becomes thick with serious doubt.
With such a budget, be sure that cryogenic companies like Alcor or Cryonics will welcome you with open arms for a freezing (-196¬∞C) scheduled right after your true-false ‚Äúdeath.‚Äù Admittedly, they are both very fringe science, but only Cryonics imposes neither a post-mortem maximum delay nor pre-cryopreservation treatment. Needless to say, upon your awakening, Liliane Bettencourt might easily outpace you in both running and sudoku. So, if you are a bit tight for full cryopreservation at Alcor (200,000 dollars), you will have a dilemma between Alcor‚Äôs ‚Äúhead option‚Äù (this is called neurocryopreservation: 80,000 dollars) and ‚Äúwhole body option‚Äù at Cryonics. It‚Äôs up to you whether immortality without sexual organs appeals to you.



‚ÄúEvitement #2‚Äù - Antoine Dor√©


Many people have heard of cryogenics without knowing what to expect exactly. And for a good reason: nobody really knows. These companies also warn that the hope placed in cryogenic techniques depends entirely on future research, whose contours we still struggle to imagine. Two equally improbable ‚Äúsolutions‚Äù loom on the horizon‚Ä¶
Firstly, you can hope for the emergence of those highly sophisticated nanorobots necessary to repair the damage freezing has done to your tissues. But to be honest, the result might not be great. As mammal bodies have been evolving for 220 million years within a temperature range of at most 25 to 45¬∞C, the chances are slim that a whole body will ever emerge intact from freezing (this is just an opinion), even if done optimally and maintained below -150¬∞C.
The second solution is probably more realistic but assumes that consciousness and mind are purely mechanical phenomena. Indeed, some researchers in the field of ‚Äúconnectomics‚Äù have recently suggested that our mind could be reduced to how our billions of neurons are interconnected. Under this hypothesis, the rapid advances in magnetic resonance imaging raise the hope of possibly extracting (from, for example, a frozen head) the information contained in these neuronal ‚Äúwiring diagrams‚Äù that constitute our mental identity. Cryogenics supporters thus argue that a computer could ‚Äúhost‚Äù a functional connectome, similar to how servers host websites today.



Representation of the human connectome - RoyalSocietyPublishing.org/Olaf Sporns


However, your burgeoning enthusiasm should be doubly tempered here. Firstly, these diagrams will necessarily be extracted with some degree of uncertainty. Upon waking, you might no longer be sure: is your mother named Marianne or Marine? Secondly, as neurons are not inert transistors but functional units that perpetually modify according to very complex and individual laws, this supercomputer would need to host not only your connectome but also reproduce these countless parameters with great fidelity. Otherwise, you risk being yourself upon waking and ‚Äúsomething‚Äù else a week later.

title: Between 1 Euro and 1 Billion: Your Budget for Eternal Life
text:
Between 1,000,000 and 1,000,000,000 euros
As a good millionaire, you no longer know what to do with your capital and you want to invest it in a long-term remunerative sector? In that case, know that immortality is an area where the notion of long-term takes on its full meaning!
Admittedly, your investments are unlikely to offer you personal immortality, but if you instill the cult of capital and social reproduction in your children and grandchildren, they might benefit from your foresight. But where to invest? Between us, the business model of cryogenics is not very promising. Opt instead for anti-aging research.
Among the companies most interested in your money, you will obviously find the irrepressible Google and its Calico laboratory. With the recruitment of the controversial Ray Kurzweil prophesying the imminent advent of a ‚Äútechnological singularity‚Äù (a sudden break in human history due to technology), Google has indeed become an openly ‚Äútranshumanist‚Äù company. Aiming both at eradicating aging and developing robotics or the rise of artificial intelligences superior to the human mind, this multinational will undoubtedly achieve some feats in anti-aging in the coming decades.
But if you prefer more family-oriented companies, you can also opt for a donation to Sens.org founded by Aubrey de Grey. This S√©bastien Tellier of immortality has crystallized many hopes since the release of his docu-advertisement ‚ÄúThe Immortalists‚Äù. With the funds he tries to collect here and there, Aubrey de Grey is pursuing several relatively serious scientific avenues. Among them, de Grey seeks to control or reverse the degeneration of ‚Äútelomeres,‚Äù these DNA sequences at the ends of chromosomes that act as natural protection against the degradation of your genetic heritage.



‚ÄúThe Immortalists‚Äù: ‚ÄúLive forever or die trying‚Äù


Indeed, it is suspected that aging is largely due to the gradual disappearance of these sequences over a lifetime, and some studies in mice indicate that by artificially reconstructing or preventing the disappearance of telomeres, it might be possible to significantly slow aging, or even reverse it! For now, this type of intervention also tends to create tumors and other metabolic instabilities, but a longevity of 200 years will likely require such treatment.
If you are ready to take all risks to curb your own aging, then I recommend putting a substantial amount into Aubrey de Grey or another similar private foundation. Their gratitude might open the doors to certain pharmacies and give you access to rapamycin, which is the first molecule recognized as effective in extending mammalian lifespan by a few percent (at the cost of some side effects already observed in mice, such as testicular degeneration or cataracts).
Unfortunately (or not), the immortality business has not yet really taken off in France and access to these experimental substances will pose more problems here. You could therefore opt for a more indirect approach if you want to invest in blue-white-red immortality. Among the possible solutions, tax-deductible donations to the CNRS, Inserm, FRM, or philanthropic organizations like the Fondation de France. These institutions also promote serious scientific research on aging, although their results are not initially reserved for the few ‚Äúhappy fews‚Äù to which you belong.

Socioeconomic Gradients, Health Gradients
While our benevolent government is about to deal a few more blows to the labor code, socioeconomic inequalities continue to translate into minds, bodies, and mortality rates [PDF]. Not to mention all the white-collar workers who suffer.
Epidemiologists and ethicists have lamented for many years the slow progress of France in prevention, and they regret that Insee limits the publication of the most useful demographic data to evaluate the phenomenon. While it is starting to subside in many European countries, the correlation between social hierarchy and health tends to worsen in France, so that the mortality rate of workers is 2.5 times higher than that of executives [p31-p32, this PDF].
The High Council for Public Health regularly reminds us of this, without much effect.

text:

Ainsi, le citoyen se retrouve dans l‚Äôexpectative et le champ des ¬´¬†v√©rit√©s possibles¬†¬ª s‚Äô√©largit d‚Äôautant¬†: √† la difficult√© de comprendre des faits d√©j√† formidablement complexes s‚Äôajoute donc une incertitude sur les faits eux-m√™mes.
Or, quels ¬´¬†outils cognitifs¬†¬ª sont √† la disposition des √™tres humains confront√©s √† une telle complexit√©¬†? Depuis deux d√©cennies, une id√©e de plus en plus r√©pandue est que notre aptitude √† percevoir et √† interpr√©ter des situations ambigu√´s provient du fait que les cerveaux humains et de primates ont √©volu√© au sein de groupes sociaux extr√™mement complexes, et ce depuis plusieurs dizaines de millions d‚Äôann√©es. Ce sont les th√©ories connues sous le nom de l‚Äô¬´¬†intelligence machiavelienne¬†¬ª, de la ¬´¬†fonction sociale de l‚Äôintelligence¬†¬ª [PDF] ou encore de l¬´¬†hypoth√®se du cerveau social¬†¬ª (liens en anglais, mais voir aussi cet article). La notion de th√©orie de l‚Äôesprit regroupe l‚Äôensemble des m√©canismes nous permettant d‚Äôexpliquer et de pr√©dire le comportement d‚Äôautrui en le ramenant aux buts que ce dernier poursuit, et de nombreuses √©tudes de neuro-imagerie ont r√©cemment r√©v√©l√© que les r√©seaux neuronaux permettant d‚Äôaccomplir ce type de d√©duction se trouvent dans des structures tr√®s √©volu√©es de notre cortex, comme la partie ant√©rieure du cortex pr√©frontal ou les p√¥les temporaux.
Cette inclination √† attribuer des intentions est si r√©pandue et si automatique que de simples figures g√©om√©triques se d√©pla√ßant sur un √©cran peuvent activer ces aires c√©r√©brales et faire l‚Äôobjet d‚Äôune attribution intentionnelle. C‚Äôest ce que l‚Äôon appelle l‚Äôillusion d‚ÄôHeider-Simmel, connue depuis 1944¬†et √©tudi√©e depuis les ann√©es 2000¬†par le groupe du chercheur Chris Frith au Royaume-Uni¬†: exemple typique d‚Äôune observation complexe qui devient explicable et pr√©dictible si l‚Äôon attribue une intention aux diff√©rents ¬´¬†protagonistes¬†¬ª.

L‚Äôillusion d‚ÄôHeider-Simmel consiste √† attribuer des intentions pour d√©crire et comprendre des √©v√©nements autrement difficilement explicables
Etant donn√© qu‚Äôune des caract√©ristiques principales de toute th√©orie du complot est de chercher une intention unique (celle d‚Äôune soci√©t√© secr√®te ou d‚Äôun conspirateur isol√©) derri√®re des √©v√©nements disparates et des co√Øncidences troublantes s‚Äôinscrivant dans le cadre d‚Äôune situation complexe, on peut penser que le conspirationnisme est une √©manation relativement naturelle de la th√©orie de l‚Äôesprit, puisqu‚Äôil permet de ramener au sein d‚Äôun cadre commun et intuitif pour l‚Äôhomme une succession d‚Äôobservations ambigu√´s et inexpliqu√©es. D‚Äôailleurs, une pathologie mentale souvent marqu√©e par la parano√Øa et l‚Äôinclination aux croyances d√©lirantes de type complotiste, la schizophr√©nie, est parfois con√ßue comme r√©sultant d‚Äôun dysfonctionnement du ¬´¬†cerveau social¬†¬ª entra√Ænant une mauvaise aptitude √† d√©tecter et √† attribuer des intentions √† autrui [PDF].
Cependant, une fois qu‚Äôune interpr√©tation conspirationniste a √©t√© √©bauch√©e, il s‚Äôagit de l‚Äô√©tayer par des faits concrets, qui sont le plus souvent manquants puisque, par d√©finition, l‚Äôinformation d√©voilant le complot est cach√©e¬†! D√®s lors, ce sont les co√Øncidences qui jouent un r√¥le majeur dans la solidification des th√®ses complotistes, parce qu‚Äôelles surprennent le lecteur et qu‚Äôelles semblent donc exiger une explication √† part enti√®re. On l‚Äôa d√©j√† √©voqu√©, la th√©orie n√©oclassique sous-tend directement la croyance dominante selon laquelle l‚Äô√©conomie de march√©, le libre-√©change, et la flexibilisation du travail constituent ensemble un mod√®le √©conomique coh√©rent qui serait valid√© par la science. A gauche, l‚Äôaire du cortex pr√©frontal dorso-lat√©ral ant√©rieur droit (en rouge) dont la r√©ponse √©tait significativement plus importante face aux individus sup√©rieurs que face aux individus inf√©rieurs. A droite, amplitude de cette diff√©rence d‚Äôactivit√© en fonction du score obtenu au questionnaire ODS qui mesure la propension √† l√©gitimer et √† renforcer les hi√©rarchies de dominance sociale.


En termes psychologiques, l‚Äôinterpr√©tation de ce r√©sultat reste d√©licat et demandera v√©rification (en th√©orie, on ne peut pas inf√©rer l‚Äôexistence d‚Äôun processus cognitif √† partir d‚Äôune activit√© c√©r√©brale), mais il est int√©ressant de noter que cette zone du cortex pr√©frontal influe sur la confiance que nous pla√ßons dans nos croyances et nos propres jugements. En r√®gle g√©n√©rale, elle est active lorsque la confiance fait d√©faut et que nous sommes incertains, tandis qu‚Äôelle est inactive lorsque nous sommes s√ªrs de nous. En augmentant ou diminuant artificiellement l‚Äôexcitabilit√© de ses neurones, on peut non seulement modifier ce sentiment de confiance √† la baisse ou √† la hausse, mais aussi interf√©rer avec la motivation et l‚Äôapprentissage dans un contexte social comp√©titif.
Quoi qu‚Äôil en soit, chez certaines personnes, l‚Äôimpact de la subordination sociale sur le cortex pr√©frontal ant√©rieur pourrait paradoxalement renforcer les attitudes favorisant le maintien ou l‚Äôexacerbation des in√©galit√©s, et donc la d√©cision de voter pour les partis de l‚Äôordre (social).
Pour en savoir plus sur la question, vous pouvez lire ce texte radical ou le communiqu√© de presse publi√© par l‚ÄôInstitut des Sciences Biologiques du CNRS, disponible ici.
*NB: Divers facteurs d√©mographiques (comme l‚Äô√¢ge, le sexe ou le niveau d‚Äô√©tudes) et divers traits de personnalit√© (li√©s au comportement social ou non) ont √©t√© pris en compte, ce qui implique que l‚Äôactivit√© c√©r√©brale mesur√©e explique une variabilit√© dans les pr√©f√©rences politiques qui n‚Äôest pas r√©ductible √† ces facteurs habituellement associ√©s √† l‚ÄôODS.

title: L‚Äôintelligence artificielle g√©n√©rale comme propri√©t√© priv√©e?
